item.description: Extended DOAC strategies-venous thromboembolism After â‰¥6 mo of anticoag, following regimens compared w/ no extended Rx (or ASA): Full-dose DOAC: * 80â€“90% â†“ recurrent VTE, 2â€“5Ã— bleeding, * but no signif excess in major bleeding * (NEJM 2010;363:2499; 2013;368:699 & 709) Â½ dose apixa or riva: * â‰¥75% â†“ recur.

item.title: Extrapulmonary TB
item.description: Extrapulmonary TB Pleural/pericardial effusions or ascites: fluid sampling for AFB cx/smear, NAAT/ PCR, cell counts. Adenosine deaminase (ADA) can be â†‘, best validated in ascites.

item.description: Extrarenal H2O loss (Uosm >700â€“800) GI H2O loss: vomiting, NGT drainage, osmotic diarrhea, fistula, lactulose, malabsorption Insensible loss: fever, exercise, ventilation, burns

item.title: Exudates

item.title: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
item.description: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (40%; CJASN 2017;12:502). Primary: permeability factor. Secondary adaptive (hyperfiltration, sickle cell, obesity, anabolic steroids, OSA, â†‘ protein, vesico-ureteral reflux); meds/toxins (IFN, bisphosphonates, NSAIDs, heroin), viral (COVID-19, HIV) or genetic (ApoL1 mutation in AA; JASN 2015;26:1443).

item.title: Folate deficiency
item.description: Folate deficiency Folate present in leafy green vegetables and fruit; total body stores sufficient for 2â€“3 mo Etiologies: malnutrition (alcoholics, anorectics, elderly), â†“ absorption (sprue), impaired metabolism (methotrexate, pyrimethamine, trimethoprim; NEJM 2015;373:1649), â†‘ requirement (chronic hemolytic anemia, pregnancy, malignancy, dialysis)

item.title: Follicular thyroid cancer
item.description: Follicular thyroid cancer Peak incidence 40 to 60 y, â™€:â™‚ 3:1; RFs: childhood radiation; FHx; familial syndrome Mortality 10â€“20% at 20 y; mets frequently distal due to hematogenous spread Hurthle cell carcinoma: pathologic dx; variant a/w poorer prognosis and â†‘ recurrence rate

item.title: Follow-up, treatment response and failure of Migraine
item.description: Follow-up, treatment response and failure of Migraine Use headache calendars Assess effectiveness and adverse events When outcomes are suboptimal, review diagnosis, treatment strategy, dosing and adherence When treatment fails, re-evaluate before changing Referral to specialist care should be reserved for patients whose condition is diagnostically challenging, difficult to treat or complicated by comorbidities

item.title: Follow-up-aortic aneurysms
item.description: Follow-up-aortic aneurysms (Circ 2010;121:e266; Nat Rev Cardiol 2011;8:92; JAMA 2013;309:806) Expansion rate ~0.1 cm/y for TAA, ~0.3â€“0.4 cm/y for AAA TAA: 6 mo after dx to ensure stable, and if stable, then annually (Circ 2005;111:816) AAA: <4 cm q2â€“3y; 4â€“5.

item.title: Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction 2018
item.description: Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction (2018) myocardial cell death due to prolonged ischemia Increases in cTnI values have not been reported to occur following injury to noncardiac tissues.

item.title: Fresh frozen plasma
item.description: Fresh frozen plasma Contains all coagulation factors. For bleeding due to defic. of multiple coag factors (eg, DIC, TTP/HUS, liver disease, dilution).

item.title: Hemothroax
item.description: Hemothroax Hemothorax is an accumulation of blood within the pleural space. Hematocrit of the pleural fluid is greater than 50% of the hematocrit of the patientâ€™s peripheral blood in hemothorax.

item.title: Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias
item.description: Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias (Chest 2012;141:e495S; NEJM 2015;373:252) Type I Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias(not clin. signif) Direct effect of heparin (non-immune) Incidence 10â€“20% After 1â€“4 d of heparin therapy Platelet nadir: >100,000/ÂµL Sequelae: None Can continue heparin and observe Type II Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias (clinically significant HIT) Immune (Ab)-mediated IgG against plt factor 4â€”heparin complex 1â€“3% with UFH, 0â€“0.

item.title: Hepatic encephalopathy HE
item.description: Hepatic encephalopathy (HE) (NEJM 2016;375:1660; Hepatology 2014; 60:715) Pathogenesis: failure of liver to detoxify NH3 + other substances (eg, ADMA; J Hepatol 2013;58:38) that cause cerebral edema, â†“ O2 consumption, â†‘ ROS â†’ brain dysfxn

item.title: Hepatic hydrothorax
item.description: Hepatic hydrothorax 2Â° diaphragmatic defect; often unilateral, R >L, Â± ascites Treatment: avoid chest tube (â†‘ complications); Rx same as ascites (TIPS if refractory).

item.title: Hepatitis A
item.description: Hepatitis A (ssRNA; 30â€“45% of acute viral hepatitis in U.S; MMWR 2018;67:1208) Transmission & RFs: fecalâ€“oral route; contam. food, water, shellfish; daycare ctr; intl travel Incubation: 2â€“6 wk; no chronic carrier state; once antibody forms â†’ lifelong immunity Sx: â†“ appetite, malaise, fever, N/V, RUQ pain, jaundice; rarely ALF (â†‘ w/ chronic HCV) Diagnosis: acute hepatitis = âŠ• IgM anti-HAV; past exposure = âŠ• IgG anti-HAV (âŠ–IgM) Rx for acute HAV: supportive care; refer to liver txplnt center if acute liver failure Vaccinate if: MSM, IVDU, chronic liver disease, international travel; Havrix (2 doses)

item.title: Hepatitis B
item.description: Hepatitis B Transmission: blood (IVDU, transfusion), sexual, perinatal (vertical) Incubation: 6 wkâ€“6 mo (mean 12â€“14 wk) Acute infxn: 70% subclinical, 30% jaundice, <1% acute liver failure (up to 60% mortality) Chronic infxn: HBsAg âŠ• >6 mo in <5% of adult-acquired (â†‘ if immunosupp), >90% of perinatal; ~40% chronic HBV â†’ cirrhosis (â†‘ risk w/ HCV, HDV, or HIV coinfxn, EtOH) HCC: â†‘ risk if cirrhosis, âŠ• FHx HCC, African >20 y old, Asian â™‚ >40 y old or â™€ >50 y old, or >40 y old w/ â†‘ ALT Â± HBV DNA >2000.

item.title: hepatitis B virus Rx duration
item.description: hepatitis B virus Rx duration (1) HBeAg âŠ• immune active w/o cirrhosis: if seroconversion (HBeAg âŠ–, anti- HBe âŠ•), can stop after 1 y if ALT nl & HBV DNA suppressed or until HBsAg clears; (2) HBeAg âŠ– immune reactivation: indefinite; (3) cirrhosis: indefinite

item.title: Hepatitis C
item.description: Hepatitis C (ssRNA; ~10% of acute viral hepatitis in U.S.; Lancet 2015;385:1124) [[Recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral (DAA) Regimens]]

item.title: hepatitis C virus acute infxn
item.description: hepatitis C virus acute infxn 80% subclinical; 10â€“20% sx hepatitis w/ jaundice; acute liver failure rare; prob of spont clearance a/w IL28B & HLA class II genotypes (Annals 2013;158:235)

item.title: hepatitis C virus extrahepatic syndromes
item.description: hepatitis C virus extrahepatic syndromes mixed cryoglobulinemia, porphyria cutanea tarda, lichen planus, leukocytoclastic vasculitis, thyroiditis, MPGN, IPF, NHL and monoclonal gammopathies

item.title: hepatitis C virus Monitoring on Rx
item.description: hepatitis C virus Monitoring on Rx CBC, INR, LFTs, GFR, HCV VL prior to starting Rx. PIs contraindicated if decomp. liver dx (ascites, encephalopathy) or CPS â‰¥7.

item.title: hepatitis C virus recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral DAA Regimens
item.description: hepatitis C virus recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral (DAA) Regimens Sofosbuvir & velpatasvir Genotypes 1â€“6, 12 weeks Rx Glecaprevir & pibrentasvir Gentotypes 1â€“6; 8 weeks Rx

item.title: hepatitis C virus Serologic, virologic, & genetic tests
item.description: hepatitis C virus Serologic, virologic, & genetic tests (screen all adults [âœ“ anti-HCV] JAMA 2020;323:970) anti-HCV (ELISA): âŠ• in 6 wk, does not = recovery or immunity; can be âŠ– after recovery

item.title: hepatitis C virus Treatment indications
item.description: hepatitis C virus Treatment indications ( www.hcvguidelines.org) (Lancet 2019;393:1453; Hepatology 2020;71:686) Acute: if no spont. clearance at 12â€“16 wk, can Rx w/ same regimens for chronic HCV Chronic: â†“ HCC & mortality.

item.title: Hepatitis D
item.description: Hepatitis D (RNA; Gastro 2019:156;461) Transmission: blood or sexual; endemic in Africa & E. Europe. Generally requires host to already have HBV infxn in order to cause co-infection or superinfection; in rare cases (immunosupp s/p liver transplant) can replicate autonomously.

item.title: Hepatitis E
item.description: Hepatitis E (ssRNA; World J Gastro 2016;22:7030; Gastro Clin N Am 2017;46:393) Most common cause of acute viral hepatitis in endemic areas

item.title: hepatocellular carcinoma
item.description: hepatocellular carcinoma Risk factors (globally, 3rd leading cause of cancer death, espec. in Africa & Asia) Cirrhosis: present in 70â€“90% HCC cases Infectious: HCV & HBV (~75%), HBV/HDV coinfection; HBV can cause HCC w/o cirrhosis Toxic: EtOH (â…“ cases in U.

item.title: Hepatopulmonary syndrome HPS
item.description: Hepatopulmonary syndrome (HPS) (Dig Dis Sci 2015;60:1914, Hepatology 2021;74:1014) Abnl gas exchange (A-a gradient â‰¥15 or PaO2 <80) caused by intrapulmonary vascular dilatations leading to intrapulmonary shunting (improves with O2) S/S: platypnea-orthodeoxia (dyspnea & hypoxia w/ sitting up), clubbing, spider angiomas Dx w/ contrast echo showing â€œlateâ€ A-V shunting (contrast in LA 3â€“6 cycles after RA) Rx: O2; potential embolization if large vessel on CT, TIPS, liver tx only definitive Rx

item.title: Hepatorenal syndrome HRS

item.description: Hornerâ€™s syndrome æ˜¯ä¸€ç¨®å½±éŸ¿èº«é«”ä¸€å´çš„é¢éƒ¨å’Œçœ¼ç›çš„ç–¾ç—…ã€‚ é€™æ˜¯ç”±æ–¼å¾å¤§è…¦åˆ°é ­éƒ¨å’Œé ¸éƒ¨çš„ç¥ç¶“é€šè·¯çš„ç ´å£å¼•èµ·çš„ã€‚ é€šå¸¸ï¼Œéœç´ç¶œåˆå¾µçš„é«”å¾µå’Œç—‡ç‹€åŒ…æ‹¬ TL;DR ç³å­”å¤§å°çš„é™ä½ï¼Œ çœ¼ç¼ä¸‹å‚ è‡‰éƒ¨å—å½±éŸ¿å´çš„å‡ºæ±—æ¸›å°‘ã€‚ Common Sings A persistently small pupil (miosis) A notable difference in pupil size between the two eyes (anisocoria) Little or delayed opening (dilation) of the affected pupil in dim light Drooping of the upper eyelid (ptosis) Slight elevation of the lower lid, sometimes called upside-down ptosis Sunken appearance of the affected eye Little or no sweating (anhidrosis) on the affected side of the face anhidrosis::no sweating

item.title: Humoral immune dysfunction

item.description: hyaline casts Casts are clusters of urinary sediment elements (red blood cells, white blood cells, fat bodies, etc.) wrapped in a protein matrix.

item.title: hyperthyroidism
item.description: hyperthyroidism [[Etiologies-hyperthyroidism]] Clinical manifestations Restlessness, sweating, tremor, moist warm skin, fine hair, tachycardia, AF, weight loss, â†‘ frequency of stools, menstrual irregularities, hyperreflexia, osteoporosis, stare and lid lag (due to sympathetic overactivity) Apathetic thyrotoxicosis: seen in elderly who can present with lethargy as only sx Laboratory testing â†‘ free T4 and total T3; â†“ TSH (except in TSH-secreting tumors) RAIU scan is very useful study to differentiate causes (see table on page 7-3); cannot do if recent IV contrast or amio load b/c iodine blocks uptake, so âœ“ autoantibodies instead Rarely need to âœ“ for autoantibodies except in pregnancy (to assess risk of fetal Gravesâ€™) May see hypercalciuria Â± hypercalcemia, â†‘ AÏ•, anemia [[Gravesâ€™ disease]] [[Thyroiditis]] [[Treatment-hyperthyroidism]] (Thyroid 2016;26:1343; JCEM 2020;105:3704) Subclinical hyperthyroidism (NEJM 2018;378:2411) Mild â†“ TSH and normal free T4 with only subtle or no sx ~15% â†’ overt hyperthyroidism in 2 y; â†‘ risk of AF, CHD, fracture (JAMA 2015;313:2055) Rx controversial: consider if TSH <0.

item.title: hypothyroidism
item.description: hypothyroidism Etiologies Primary (>90% of cases of hypothyroidism; â†“ free T4, â†‘ TSH) Goitrous: [[Hashimotoâ€™s thyroiditis]] (after hyperthyroid phase of thyroiditis), iodine deficiency, lithium, amiodarone Nongoitrous: surgical destruction, s/p radioactive iodine or XRT, amiodarone Secondary (central): â†“ free T4; TSH low, inappropriately nl, or slightly high (although functionally inactive due to abnormal glycosylation); due to hypothalamic or pituitary failure Hashimotoâ€™s thyroiditis Clinical manifestations (Annals 2020;173:ITC1) Early: weakness, fatigue, arthralgias, myalgias, headache, depression, cold intolerance, weight gain, constipation, menorrhagia, dry skin, coarse brittle hair, brittle nails, carpal tunnel syndrome, delayed DTRs (â€œhung upâ€ reflexes), diastolic HTN, hyperlipidemia Late: slow speech; hoarseness; loss of outer third of eyebrows; myxedema (nonpitting skin thickening due to â†‘ glycosaminoglycans); periorbital puffiness; bradycardia; pleural, pericardial, & peritoneal effusions; atherosclerosis Myxedema crisis: vide infra Diagnostic studies (Lancet 2017;390:1550) â†“ free T4; â†‘ TSH in 1Âº hypothyroidism; âŠ• antithyroid Ab (TPO) in Hashimotoâ€™s thyroiditis May see hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, anemia, â†‘ LDL, â†“ HDL and â†‘ CK Screening recommended for pregnant women [[Treatment of overt hypothyroidism]] (Endocrine 2019;66:18) [[Subclinical hypothyroidism]] (NEJM 2017;376:2556; JAMA 2019;322:153) [[Myxedema coma]] (ie, profound hypothyroidism; Thyroid 2014;24:1670) Backlinkï¼š [[amiodarone and thyroid disease]] [[Central hypothyroidism]] [[Common Diagnostic Tests in Thyroid Disorders]] [[Differential Diagnosis of Delirium]] [[Dyslipidemias]] [[Etiologies of Acute Pericarditis]] [[Etiologies of Classic FUO]] [[Etiologies of Prolonged-QT-interval]] [[Euvolemic-hypotonic-hyponatremia]] [[Heart failure with preserved EF]] [[Hyperprolactinemia]] [[hypopituitary syndromes]] [[Myxedema coma]] [[nonthyroidal illness (sick euthyroid syndrome) ]] [[# The Profession of Medicine PA RT 1 ]] [[Physical Exam Secret]] [[respiratory-acidosis]] [[Subclinical hypothyroidism]] [[Thyroiditis]] [[thyroid disorders]] [[Treatment of overt hypothyroidism]] [[Treatment-hypopituitary syndromes]] [[Washington Manual Thyroid Disorders]] [[workup-hyponatremia]]

item.title: IgA nephropathy
item.description: IgA nephropathy (CJASN 2017;12:677; AJKD 2021;78:429) Most common cause of GN; â™‚ pred; peak incidence 20â€“30s; can also be post-infectious Wide range of clinical presentations: asx hematuria (30â€“40%), gross hematuria ~1â€“3 d after URI (10â€“15%), chronic GN (10%), nephrotic syndrome (5%), RPGN (<5%) Though clinical presentation can be highly suggestive, definitive dx only w/ bx Prognosis: â†‘Cr, HTN, proteinuria a/w poor prog.

item.description: IgA vasculitis (formerly Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura [HSP]) (Rheumatol 2019;58:1607) IgA-mediated [[small-vessel vasculitis]] w/ predilectionåå¥½ for skin, GI tract, and kidneys Epidemiology: * incidence 140/million/y; * å†¬å¤©çš„å¥³å­© * â™‚ >â™€, * children >adults, * winter >summer * May develop ~10 d after onset of upper resp infx or after drug exposure [[Clinical manifestations of IgA vasculitis]] Dx studies: skin bx w/ immunofluorescence â†’ leukocytoclastic vasculitis w/ IgA and C3 deposition in vessel wall; renal bx â†’ mesangial IgA deposition Treatment: * often self-limiting over 4 wk; * steroids Â± DMARDs for renal or severe disease [Henoch-Schonlein purpura | Circulatory System and Disease | NCLEX-RN | Khan Academy - YouTube]( https://www.

item.title: incidence of vasculitides
item.description: incidence of vasculitides reported to be 40-60 cases per 1 million persons, with giant cell arteritis (GCA) being the most common type of primary systemic vasculitis among adults, particularly those aged > 50 years.

item.title: Indications for Permanent Pacing
item.description: Indications for Permanent Pacing (JACC 2013;61:e6 & 2017;70:e39, Circ 2019;140:e382) AV block 2Â° type II, high-grade or 3Â° AVB; symptomatic 1Â°, 2Â° type I AVB or asx with Lamin A/C or neuromuscular disease; bifasc or alter.

item.description: Indications for surgery-bacterial endocarditis (consult early; JTCS 2017;153:1241; Circ 2021;143:e72) Emergent if refractory cardiogenic shock Urgent (during initial hospitalization): Sx HF Penetrating infection: periannular abscess, heart block, fistula, worsening conduction Persistent infection: âŠ• BCx after >5 d of appropriate abx, â†‘ or ?

item.title: Initial antibiotic therapy of fever and neutropenia
item.description: Initial antibiotic therapy of fever and neutropenia Empiric regimens should include antipseudomonal activity; consider VRE coverage if âŠ• Low risk: PO abx or home IV abx may be considered in select Pts (JCO 2013;31:1149) PO options: cipro+amoxicillin-clavulanate; levofloxacin; moxifloxacin (avoid if FQ Ppx) High risk: hospital admission & IV abx; monotherapy preferred options: cefepime, imipenem, meropenem, piperacillin/tazobactam, ceftazidime Antifungal Rx added for neutropenic fever â‰¥4 d despite abx: micafungin, liposomal amphotericin B, caspofungin, anidulafungin, voriconazole, & posaconazole are options

item.description: Initial evaluation diagnostic studies-acute aortic syndromes (Circ 2010;121:e266; EHJ 2018;39:739) H&P, incl. bilat BP & radial pulses for symmetry; ECG w/ STE if propagates to cor CXR: abnl in 60â€“90% [â†‘ mediast.

item.title: Initial evaluation of change in mental status
item.description: Initial evaluation of change in mental status see [[Stepwise Evaluation of a Patient with Delirium]] History (witness & background crucial): tempo, premorbid sx (eg, focal neuro deficits, HA, infxn, pain, falls), medical conditions (eg, dementia, epilepsy, onc, cardiac, psych, infection/immune status), accompanied by head trauma, current meds (eg, sedatives, opioids, anticoag, anticonvulsants, immunosuppressants), drug/alcohol use General exam: VS, breathing pattern (eg, Cheyne-Stokes), tongue bite (seizure), nuchal rigidity (meningitis, SAH; do not test if c/f trauma/cervical spine fx), ecchymoses, rash, signs of head trauma (eg, Battle sign, raccoon eyes, hemotympanum, CSF rhinorrhea), asterixis, liver disease stigmata, embolic phenomena/endocarditis, s/s drug use Neuro exam

item.title: Initial evaluation-management-inflammatory bowel disease

item.title: initial test of hypophosphatemia
item.description: initial test of hypophosphatemia serum calcium, vitamin D, and parathyroid hormone levels; arterial blood gas; urine phosphorus and creatinine levels; fractional excretion of phosphorus; fractional excretion of phosphorus < 5% suggests a nonrenal mechanism (intracellular uptake or gastrointestinal); x-ray, if osteomalacia is suspected.

item.title: ischemic colitis
item.description: ischemic colitis Definition & pathophysiology Nonocclusive disease 2Â° to Î”s in systemic circulation or anatomic/fxnal Î”s in local mesenteric vasculature; often underlying etiology unknown, frequently seen in elderly â€œWatershedâ€ areas (splenic flexure & rectosigmoid) most susceptible; 25% involve R side; confers worse prognosis (Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2015;13:1969) Clinical manifestations, diagnosis, & treatment Usually p/w cramping LLQ pain w/ overtly bloody stool; fever and peritoneal signs should raise clinical suspicion for infarction Disease spectrum: reversible colopathy (35%), transient colitis (15%), chronic ulcerating colitis (20%), resulting stricture (10%), gangrene (15%), fulminant colitis (<5%) Dx: flex sig/colonoscopy or CT abd/pelvis to make diagnosis; r/o IBD, infectious colitis Treatment: bowel rest, IV fluids, broad-spectrum abx, serial abd exams; surgery for infarction, fulminant colitis, hemorrhage, failure of med Rx, recurrent sepsis, stricture Resolution w/in 48 h w/ conservative measures occurs in >50% of cases

item.title: Kawasaki disease
item.description: Kawasaki disease Usually Asian children < 4 years old. CRASH Conjunctivitis, Bilateral nonexudative bulbar Rash (polymorphous desquamating), Adenopathy (cervical) Strawberry tongue (oral mucositis), Hand-foot changes (edema, erythema), Burn: fever.

item.title: ketamine
item.description: ketamine contraindicated in patients with underlying conditions in which increased blood pressure would pose a risk of complications such as aortic dissection, uncontrolled hypertension, myocardial infarction, or aneurysms.

item.title: KEYNOTE-181
item.description: KEYNOTE-181 Purpose: Patients with advanced esophageal cancer have a poor prognosis and limited treatment options after first-line chemotherapy. Patients and methods: In this open-label, phase III study, we randomly assigned (1:1) 628 patients with advanced/metastatic squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, that progressed after one prior therapy, to pembrolizumab 200 mg every 3 weeks for up to 2 years or chemotherapy (investigator’s choice of paclitaxel, docetaxel, or irinotecan).

item.title: Loop diuretics
item.description: Loop diuretics (NEJM 2017;377:1964) Drugs: furosemide (Lasix), torsemide, bumetanide (Bumex), ethacrynic acid [[Mechanisms-Loop diuretics]] Dosing: bioavailability PO furosemide ~50%, PO torsemide & bumetanide ~90% 40 mg IV = 80 mg PO Lasix = 20 mg PO/IV torsemide = 1 mg IV/PO bumetanide Dose furosemide bid-qid; qd dosing can yield initial diuresis, but then anti-natriuresis.

item.title: Low-voltage
item.description: Low-voltage QRS amplitude (R + S) <5 mm in all limb leads & <10 mm in all precordial leads

item.title: lumbar puncture after brain imaging
item.description: lumbar puncture after brain imaging A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head is frequently ordered by clinicians prior to performing a lumbar puncture (LP) to rule out an intracranial abnormality with elevated intracranial pressure

item.title: lung cancer
item.description: lung cancer [[Epidemiology and risk factors-lung cancer]] Screening ([[JAMA 2021;325:962]]) Annual low-dose chest CT in â‰¥20 pack-year current or former (quit w/in 15 y) smokers, age 50â€“80 y â†’ 20% â†“ lung cancer-related mortality (NEJM 2020;382:503) High rates of screen-detected nodules.

item.title: lung transplant
item.description: lung transplant Overview Indications: end stage, progressive decline despite max medical Rx, <2-y life expectancy; COPD, ILD (IPF), pulmonary HTN, cystic fibrosis, alpha 1-antitrypsin Contraindic: age >70, uncontrolled/unRxâ€™d infxn, malig in prior 5 yrs, severe non-pulm dis.

item.description: Major-risk-factor-modification-stable ischemic heart disease Lipids: statin (typically high-intensity) Â± ezetimibe & PCSK9i (see â€œDyslipidemiaâ€) BP <130/80 (see â€œHypertensionâ€); in SIHD may opt for ACEI and Î²B (if angina) Diabetes management (qv): HbA1c â‰¤7% and consider GLP1RA or SGLT2i Smoking cessation; influenza vaccine Diet (â†‘ vegetables, fruits, whole grains; â†“ saturated fat, trans fatty acids, sweets, red meat, Na); target BMI 18.

item.title: Malignancy workup-adrenal incidentalomas
item.description: Malignancy workup-adrenal incidentalomas CT and MRI characteristics may suggest adenoma vs. carcinoma Benign features: unenhanced CT <10 Hounsfield units or CT contrast-medium washout >50% at 10 min; size <4 cm; smooth margins, homogenous and hypodense appearance; can follow such incidentalomas w/ periodic scans Suspicious features: size â‰¥4 cm or â†‘ size on repeat scan; >10 Hounsfield units on CT, irregular margins, heterogeneous, dense or vascular appearance; h/o malignancy or young age.

item.description: Mallory-Weiss tear GE jxn lacerations due to vomiting â†’ â†‘ intraabd pressure & shearing Often self-resolve; Rxâ†’ antiemetics, PPI, endoscopic therapy

item.title: management of Barrettâ€™s esophagitis
item.description: management of Barrettâ€™s esophagitis PPI. W/o dysplasia: surveillance EGD q3â€“5y. Low-grade dysplasia: EGD q12mo; possible endoscopic eradication. High-grade dysplasia: endoscopic eradication; consider chemoprophylaxis w/ high-dose PPI & ASA (Lancet 2018;392:400).

item.description: Management of ICU patient-pulmonary hypertension Avoid tachyarrhythmias & overly aggressive volume resuscitation Caution w/ vasodilators if any L-sided dysfunction

item.description: Management-solitary pulmonary nodule Low risk (<5%): serial CT (freq depending on risk); shared decision w/ Pt re: bx

item.title: Managing complications of Migraine
item.description: Managing complications of Migraine Identify comorbid conditions Select drugs and adiust their use according to comorbidities present Alleviate comborbidities if possible to improve outcome

item.title: Managing complications-acute kidney injury AKI
item.description: Managing complications-acute kidney injury (AKI) May take 1â€“3 wk to recover from ATN; anticipate volume overload, â†‘ K, â†‘ PO4, acidosis

item.title: Managing migraine in special populations
item.description: Managing migraine in special populations Older people Secondary headache, comorbidities and adverse events are all more likely Poor evidence base for all drugs in this age group Children and adolescents Be aware that presentation can differ from migraine in adults Parents and schools have important roles in the management of young children Bed rest alone can be sufficient Use ibuprofen for acute treatment and propranolol, amitriptyline or topiramate for prevention Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding Use paracetamol for acute treatment Avoid preventive treatment if possible Women with menstrual migraine Perimenstrual preventive therapy with long-acting NSAID or triptan

item.title: Markdownify
item.description: To import a URL as Markdown, turn on the option under “Editing” in nvALT’s Preferences. Now, when you drag a URL to the notes list, it will convert it to Markdown as much as possible.

item.title: MASCC Risk Index
item.description: MASCC Risk Index Use in neutropenic patients (see ANC calculator) with fever at least 100.4Â°F (38ÂºC). Do not use in patients with acute leukemia undergoing induction chemotherapy or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant conditioning, per IDSA guidelines.

item.title: mechanisms of hypophosphatemia
item.description: mechanisms of hypophosphatemia Intracellular uptake of phosphate from the extracellular fluid #anki acute respiratory alkalosis: increased intracellular pH stimulates phosphofructokinase activity and glycolysis which leads to intracellular uptake of phosphate; hyperventilation (caused for example by sepsis, anxiety, diabetic ketoacidosis, or other underlying conditions) can precipitate intracellular shift of phosphate into cells; refeeding of malnourished patients; administration of insulin or glucose (which stimulates insulin secretion); hungry bone syndrome.

item.title: Mechanisms-Loop diuretics
item.description: Mechanisms-Loop diuretics inhib NaK2Cl cotransporter in thick ascending limb (ThAL, site of 25% Na reabsorp) â†’ â†“ medullary osmotic gradient & â†“ free H2O reabsorption via ADH

item.title: Meckelâ€™s diverticulum
item.description: Meckelâ€™s diverticulum Congenital intestinal pouch due to incomplete obliteration of vitelline duct. 2% of pop, w/in 2â€² of IC valve, 2â€³ long, â™‚:â™€ 2:1, can present as obscure GIB in adults.

item.title: Medullary thyroid cancer
item.description: Medullary thyroid cancer Neuroendocrine tumor of C cells, peak incidence 40 to 60 y, a/w MEN2A and MEN2B Most commonly solitary nodule; calcitonin production (presents with diarrhea, flushing) and level used to trend dz progression, dx w/ FNA (Se 50â€“80%); mortality 25â€“50% at 5 y Surgery first-line treatment

item.title: Methotrexate
item.description: Methotrexate MTX is a folic acid antagonist. DNA synthesis is inhibited by inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase, which provides reduced folates for purine synthesis.

item.title: methylprednisolone
item.description: methylprednisolone [[acute respiratory distress syndrome]] IV (succinate): Loading dose of 1 mg/kg over 30 minutes, 1 to 14: 1 mg/kg/day in divided doses or as a continuous infusion.

item.title: MI in absence of obstructive CAD
item.description: MI in absence of obstructive CAD Definition: MI but w/o coronary stenosis â‰¥50% in any major epicardial vessel More common in younger Pts, women, Black/Pacific race or Hispanic Advanced coronary imaging (eg, OCT) & cardiac MRI to exclude missed coronary obstruction, other causes of myocyte injury (eg, myocarditis), other causes of â†‘ Tn (eg, PE) ~75% ischemic (ie, plaque disruption identified) and 25% alternative dx (eg, myocarditis)

item.title: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia MMVT
item.description: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (MMVT) All beats look similar; predominantly upward in V1 = RBBB-type vs. downward = LBBB-type In obviously structurally abnormal heart: prior MI (scar); CMP In apparently nl heart that is actually diseased: subtle HCM, infiltrative CMP, myocarditis, arrhythmogenic CMP (ACM): incomplete RBBB, Îµ wave (terminal notch in QRS) & TWI in V1â€“V3 on resting ECG LBBB-type VT, dx w/ MRI (Lancet 2009;373:1289) In structurally normal heart w/ normal resting ECG & cardiac MRI: RVOT VT: LBBB-type VT or PVCs w/ inferior axis; typically ablate LVOT VT: RBBB-type VT or PVCs w/ superior axis; responds to verapamil

item.description: myocarditis Etiologies [[infectious myocarditis]] [[autoimmune myocarditis]] Clinical manifestations Highly variable, ranging from incidental dx based on labs/imaging to fulminant HF w/ shock Can present as ACS-like syndrome (chest pain, ECG Î”s, â†‘ Tn), acute HF, arrhythmias Diagnostic studies and workup Echo: systolic dysfxn (typically global but can be regional); Â± â†‘ LV wall thickness due to edema; LV size may be small in fulminant and dilated in chronic; Â± pericardial effusion Cardiac MRI: can show hyperemia, edema, and scar (JACC 2009;53:1475) Endomyocardial biopsy: useful in GCM & eosinophilic; âˆ´ consider if rapidly progressive HF, high-grade AVB or sustained VT, suspected allergic rxn or eosinophilia Treatment Standard HF Rx if LV dysfxn (but do not start if e/o shock); temporary MCS as needed Immunosuppression: for GCM (high-dose steroids + CsA or tacrolimus Â± AZA), collagen vascular disease, peripartum (?

item.title: Other diagnostic studies-syncope
item.description: Other diagnostic studies-syncope (consider based on results of H&P and ECG) Ambulatory ECG monitoring: if suspect arrhythmogenic syncope Holter monitoring (continuous ECG 24â€“72 h): useful if frequent events Event recorder (activated by Pt to record rhythm): limited role if LOC w/o prodrome External loop recorder (continuously saves rhythm, âˆ´ can be activated after an event): useful for episodes (including w/o prodrome) likely to occur w/in 2â€“6 wks; can be coupled w/ mobile cardiac telemetry than can be auto-triggered for specific rhythms External patch recorder (1-lead recording; saves for 1â€“4 wks): Pt-activated or auto-triggered; more comfortable for Pts Implantable loop recorders (SC; can record 2â€“3 y; can be triggered): useful if episodes <1/mo; dx in 55% of cases; recommended for recurrent syncope w/o prodrome Echo: consider to r/o structural heart disease (eg, CMP [incl HCMP & ARVC], valvular disease [incl AS, MS, MVP], myxoma, amyloid, PHT, Â± anomalous coronaries) ETT/CCTA/Cath: esp.

item.description: pathogenesis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) massive activation of coagulation that overwhelms control mechanisms Thrombosis in microvasculature â†’ ischemia + microangiopathic hemolytic anemia

item.title: pathogenesis of vasculitides
item.description: pathogenesis of vasculitides is not well understood, but potential pathophysiologic processes leading to vascular damage include immune complex deposition, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) (humoral mechanism), and T-lymphocyte response with granuloma formation (cell-mediated mechanism).

item.description: Pathophysiology risk factors -aortic aneurysms (JACC 2020:76:201 & 2021;78:201) Medial degen and/or â†‘ wall stress; wall stress âˆ [(âˆ†P Ã— r) / (wall thickness)] (Laplaceâ€™s law) TAA: medial degeneration (muscle apoptosis, elastin fiber weakening); a/w CTD, aortitis AAA: long-standing HTN + athero/inflammation â†’ medial weakening Clinical risk factors: HTN, athero, smoking, age, â™‚, presence of other aortic dilation CTD (Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos type IV, Loeys-Dietz); congenital (bicuspid AoV, Turnerâ€™s) aortitis (Takayasuâ€™s GCA, spondyloarthritis, IgG4); infection (eg, syphilis); FQ; trauma

item.title: pathophysiology gastroesophageal reflux disease
item.description: pathophysiology gastroesophageal reflux disease (JAMA 2020;324:2536) â†‘ acid exposure in esophagus, caused by â†‘ transient LES relaxations. Worsened by â†‘ intraabd pressure (eg, obesity, pregnancy), â†“ esophagogastric motility, hiatal hernia.

item.title: Pathophysiology of Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
item.description: Pathophysiology of Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis Type I: cryo precipitation in microcirculation â†’ hyperviscosity & vascular occlusion Types II/III: defective/insufficient immune complex (IC) clearance â†’ IC-mediated inflammation of blood vessels w/ complement activation â†’ vasculitis

item.title: Pathophysiology of diverticulitis
item.description: Pathophysiology of diverticulitis (NEJM 2007;357:2057; Gastro 2015;149:1944) Retention of undigested food and bacteria in diverticulum â†’ fecalith formation â†’ obstruction â†’ compromise of diverticulumâ€™s blood supply, infection, microperforation Uncomplicated (75%): microperforation â†’ localized infection, LLQ pain, fever, â†‘ WBC Complicated (25%): macroperf â†’ abscess, peritonitis, fistula (65% w/ bladder), obstrxn Clinical manifestations LLQ abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhea PEx ranges from LLQ tenderness Â± palpable mass to peritoneal signs & septic shock Ddx includes IBD, infectious colitis, PID, tubal pregnancy, cystitis, colorectal cancer

item.description: Pathophysiology of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy LV outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) in â‰¥70%: narrowed tract 2Â° hypertrophied septum + systolic anterior motion (SAM) of ant.

item.description: Pathophysiology-Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity 90% of acetaminophen (N-acetyl-p-aminophenol, APAP) metab into nontoxic metab, but ~5% metab by CYP2E1 into NAPQI, a hepatotoxic metab detoxified by glutathione conjugation; APAP overdose (>10 g) depletes glutathione stores â†’ injury

item.title: Pathophysiology-ascites
item.description: Pathophysiology-ascites ( Hepatology 2021;74:1014) [[Pathogenesis of ascites and related complications of cirrhosis]] Portal HTN â†’ â†‘ NO & prostaglandins â†’ splanchnic vasodilatationâ†’ â†“ effective arterial volume â†’ â†‘ RAAS & ADH â†’ renal Na & H2O retention â†’ volume overload and ascites Portal hypertension leads to increased nitric oxide and prostaglandins, resulting in splanchnic vasodilation and decreased effective arterial volume.

item.title: Pathophysiology-constrictive pericarditis
item.description: Pathophysiology-constrictive pericarditis Adhesion of visceral and parietal pericardial layers â†’ rigid pericardium that limits diastolic filling of ventricles â†’ â†‘ systemic venous pressures Venous return is limited only after early rapid filling phase; âˆ´ rapid â†“ in RA pressure with atrial relaxation and opening of tricuspid valve and prominent x and y descents Kussmaul sign: JVP does not decrease with inspiration (â†‘ venous return with inspiration, but negative intrathoracic pressure not transmitted to heart because of rigid pericardium)

item.title: Pathophysiology-diabetic ketoacidosis
item.description: Pathophysiology-diabetic ketoacidosis (NEJM 2015;372:546) Occurs in T1D (and in ketosis-prone T2D); â†‘ glucagon and â†“ insulin Hyperglycemia due to: â†‘ gluconeogenesis, â†‘ glycogenolysis, â†“ glucose uptake into cells Ketosis due to: insulin deficiency â†’ mobilization and oxidation of fatty acids, â†‘ substrate for ketogenesis, â†‘ ketogenic state of the liver, â†“ ketone clearance

item.description: Pathophysiology-gastroesophageal reflux disease Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is the second most common gastrointestinal diagnosis in the ambulatory setting and affects 18%â€“28% of people living in the North America.

item.title: Pathophysiology-Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias
item.description: Pathophysiology-Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenias Ab binds heparin-PF4 â†’ immune complex binds to plt â†’ plt activation, further PF4 release â†’ plt aggregates removed from circulation â†’ thrombocytopenia; procoagulants released by plts and tissue factor released by endothelial cells damaged by HIT Abs â†’ prothrombotic state

item.description: Pathophysiology-hypernatremia (Crit Care 2013;17:206; NEJM 2015;372:55) Deficit of water relative to sodium; by definition, all hypernatremic Pts are hypertonic

item.title: Pathophysiology-hyponatremia
item.description: Pathophysiology-hyponatremia (JASN 2008;19:1076; NEJM 2015;372:1349) Pathophysiology (JASN 2008;19:1076; NEJM 2015;372:1349) Excess H2O relative to Na, usually due to â†‘ ADH â†‘ ADH may be appropriate (eg, hypovolemia or hypervolemia with â†“ EAV) â†‘ ADH may be inappropriate (SIADH) Rarely, â†“ ADH (appropriately suppressed), but kidneys unable to maintain nl [Na]serum at steady state, solute intake = solute excretion; urine output = solute excretion/Uosm nl dietary solute load ~750 mOsm/d, min Uosm = 50 mOsm/L, âˆ´ UOP can be up to ~15 L â†‘ H2O intake (1Â° polydipsia): ingestion of massive quantities (usually >15 L/d) of free H2O overwhelms diluting ability of kidney â†’ H2O retention â†“ solute intake (â€œtea & toastâ€ & beer potomania): â†“â†“ daily solute load â†’ insufficient solute to excrete H2O intake (eg, if only 250 mOsm/d, minimum Uosm = 50 mOsm/L â†’ excrete in ~5 L; if H2O ingestion exceeds this amount â†’ H2O retention)

item.description: Periprocedural â€œBridgingâ€ of Anticoagulation in Pts with Mechanical Valve(s) AVR w/o risk factors d/c warfarin 2â€“4 d before surg; restart 12â€“24 h after surg

item.title: Peritoneal dialysis PD
item.description: Peritoneal dialysis (PD) (JAMA 2017;317:1864) Fluid removed via convection using oncotic pressure (eg, dextrose). â†‘ concentrations and dwell times removes more fluid (less as glc equilibrates).

item.title: Peritoneal dialysis-associated-Bacterial peritonitis
item.description: Peritoneal dialysis-associated-Bacterial peritonitis cloudy fluid, abd pain, fever, nausea. Dx can be made with >50 PMNs. Culture most often GPC (50%) or GNR (15%).

item.title: Pharmacologic options-Treatment-hypertension
item.description: Pharmacologic options-Treatment-hypertension Pre-HTN: ARB prevents onset of HTN, no â†“ in clinical events (NEJM 2006;354:1685) HTN: choice of therapy controversial, concomitant disease and stage may help guide Rx; ?

item.title: Pharmacologic-stress-test
item.description: Pharmacologic-stress-test Use if unable to exercise, low exercise tolerance, or recent MI. Se & Sp â‰ˆ exercise. Preferred if LBBB, WPW or V-paced, because higher prob of false âŠ• imaging with exercise

item.title: phosphate replacement therapies
item.description: phosphate replacement therapies In adults with symptomatic mild hypophosphatemia (2-2.5 mg/dL [0.65-0.81 mmol/L]) treat with increased dietary phosphate or oral phosphate supplements 1,000-2,000 mg/day.

item.title: Physical exam of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
item.description: Physical exam of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy Sustained PMI, S2 paradoxically split if severe outflow obstruction, âŠ• S4 (occ. palpable)

item.title: Physical Exam Secret
item.description: Physical Exam Secret Postural dizziness (severe enough to stop the test) or an increase in heart rate of at least 30 beats/minute has sensitivity of 97% and specificity of 96% for blood loss >630 mL.

item.title: Physical exam-acute bacterial meningitis
item.description: Physical exam-acute bacterial meningitis Brudzinski and Kernig signs of meningeal irritation appear unreliable for diagnosis or ruling out of meningitis.

item.title: Physical exam-bacterial endocarditis
item.description: Physical exam-bacterial endocarditis Cardiac murmur (85%), s/s of new HF (pulmonary edema, JVP elevation, edema) Skin/ocular changes (uncommon but highly specific) Janeway lesions (painless hemorrhagic macules on palms/ soles due to septic emboli) Oslerâ€™s nodes (painful nodules on pads of digits due to immune complex deposition) Splinter hemorrhages in fingernails or toenails Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages) MSK: point tenderness along spine, red/hot joints Neurologic deficits c/f embolic stroke; vertebral tenderness c/f osteo or epidural abscess Devices: evaluate CVCs, PM/ICD pocket, and sites of other hardware/ prosthetics

item.title: Physical exam-cirrhosis
item.description: Physical exam-cirrhosis Liver: initially enlarged, palpable (L lobe predom), firm; eventually shrunken, nodular Signs of liver failure: jaundice (bili >2.

item.title: Physical exam-constrictive pericarditis
item.description: Physical exam-constrictive pericarditis â†‘ JVP with prominent y descent, âŠ• Kussmaul sign [Ddx: tricuspid stenosis, acute cor pulmonale, RV dysfxn (CMP, RV MI), SVC syndrome] Hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, peripheral edema.

item.title: Physical exam-mitral-stenosis
item.description: Physical exam-mitral-stenosis Low-pitched mid-diastolic rumble at apex w/ presystolic accentuation (if not in AF); best heard in L lat decubitus position during expiration, â†‘ w/ exercise; severity proportional to duration (not intensity) of murmur; loud S 1 Opening snap (high-pitched early diastolic sound at apex) from fused leaflet tips; MVA proportional to S2â€“OS interval (tighter valve â†’ â†‘ LA pressure â†’ shorter interval) Loud S1 (unless MV calcified and immobile)

item.title: Physical exam-pericardial tamponade
item.description: Physical exam-pericardial tamponade Beckâ€™s triad (present in minority of cases): distant heart sounds (28%), â†‘ JVP (76%) w/ blunted y descent, hypotension (26%); Â± pericardial friction rub (30%) Reflex tachycardia (77%), cool extremities Pulsus paradoxus (Se 82%, Sp 70%) = â†“ SBP â‰¥10 mmHg during inspiration âŠ• LR 3.

item.title: Physical exam-pericarditis and pericardial effusion
item.description: Physical exam-pericarditis and pericardial effusion Pericarditis: multiphasic friction rub best heard at LLSB w/ diaphragm of stethoscope. Notoriously variable and evanescent leathery sound w/ up to 3 components: atrial contraction, ventricular contraction, ventricular relaxation (NEJM 2012;367:e20).

item.title: Physical Examination
item.description: Physical Examination Wheezing and prolonged expiratory phase Presence of nasal polyps, rhinitis, rash â†’ allergic component

item.title: Physical-exam-aortic-regurgitation
item.description: Physical-exam-aortic-regurgitation Early diastolic decrescendo murmur at LSB (RSB if dilated Ao root); â†‘ w/ sitting forward, expir, handgrip; severity of AR âˆ duration of murmur (except in acute and severe late); Austin Flint murmur: mid-to-late diastolic rumble at apex (AR jet interfering w/ mitral inflow) Wide pulse pressure due to â†‘ stroke volume, hyper-dynamic pulse; pulse pressure narrows in late AR with â†“ LV fxn; bisferiens (twice-beating) arterial pulse PMI diffuse and laterally displaced; soft S1 (early closure of MV); Â± S3 (â‰ â†“ EF but rather just volume overload in AR)

item.title: Physical-exam-aortic-stenosis
item.description: Physical-exam-aortic-stenosis Midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at RUSB, harsh, high-pitched, radiates to carotids, apex (holosystolic = Gallavardin effect), â†‘ w/ passive leg raise, â†“ w/ standing & Valsalva.

item.title: Physical-exam-mitral-regurgitation
item.description: Physical-exam-mitral-regurgitation Early diastolic decrescendo murmur at LSB (RSB if dilated Ao root); â†‘ w/ sitting forward, expir, handgrip; severity of AR âˆ duration of murmur (except in acute and severe late); Austin Flint murmur: mid-to-late diastolic rumble at apex (AR jet interfering w/ mitral inflow) Wide pulse pressure due to â†‘ stroke volume, hyper-dynamic pulse; pulse pressure narrows in late AR with â†“ LV fxn; bisferiens (twice-beating) arterial pulse PMI diffuse and laterally displaced; soft S1 (early closure of MV); Â± S3 (â‰ â†“ EF but rather just volume overload in AR) Classic Eponymous Signs in Chronic AR Corriganâ€™s pulse â€œwater hammerâ€ pulse (ie, rapid rise/fall or distention/collapse) Hillâ€™s sign (popliteal SBP â€“ brachial SBP) >60 mmHg Duroziezâ€™s sign to-and-fro murmur heard over femoral artery w/ light compression Pistol shot sounds pistol shot sound heard over femoral artery Traubeâ€™s sound double sound heard over femoral artery when compressed distally de Mussetâ€™s sign head-bobbing with each heartbeat (low Se) MÃ¼llerâ€™s sign systolic pulsations of the uvula Quinckeâ€™s pulses subungual capillary pulsations (low Sp)

item.title: Pituitary apoplexy
item.description: Pituitary apoplexy Rapid expansion of pituitary tumor (typically adenoma) due to hemorrhage or infarction Sx include excruciating headache, diplopia, hypopituitarism Rx: immediate high-dose glucocorticoids; prompt surgical decompression if severe neurologic impairment or Î” MS; conservative management if mild

item.title: Pituitary tumors
item.description: Pituitary tumors Pathophysiology: adenoma â†’ excess of trophic hormone (if tumor fxnal, but 30â€“40% not) and potentially deficiencies in other trophic hormones due to compression; cosecretion of PRL and growth hormone in 10% of prolactinomas Clinical manifestations: specific syndromes due to oversecretion of hormones (see below) Â± non-specific mass effect: headache, visual Î”s, diplopia, cranial neuropathies Workup: MRI brain pituitary protocol, hormone levels, Â± visual field testing if <10 mm, no mass effect, no hormone overproduction, can f/up in 12 mos

item.description: Placement PA catheter and tailored therapy Insertion site: R IJ or L subclavian veins preferred for â€œanatomicâ€ flotation into PA

item.description: Pneumocystis jiroveci (PCP) pneumonia fever, night sweats, dyspnea on exertion, dry (â€œdoorstopâ€) cough CXR w/ interstitial pattern, â†“ PaO2, â†‘ A-a âˆ‡, â†‘ LDH, âŠ• PCP sputum stain, âŠ• Î²-glucan Rx if PaO2 >70: TMP-SMX 15â€“20 mg of TMP/kg divided tid, avg dose = DS 2 tabs PO tid Rx if PaO2 <70 or A-a gradient >35: prednisone before abx (40 mg PO bid; â†“ after 5 d) HIV âŠ• smokers much more likely to die from lung cancer than OI (JAMA 2017;177:1613)

item.title: Polyarteritis nodosa
item.description: Polyarteritis nodosa Usually middle-aged males. Hepatitis B seropositivity in 30% of patients. Fever, weight loss, malaise, headache. GI: abdominal pain, melena.

item.title: Polycystic kidney disease
item.description: Polycystic kidney disease (NEJM 2008;359:1477; 2017;377:1988) Mostly AD PKD1/PKD2 mutations â†’ renal cysts. PKD1 (85%) younger-onset ESRD. Rx: hydration, low-salt diet; tolvaptan reduces GFR decline.

item.title: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia PMVT
item.description: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (PMVT) QRS morphology changes from beat to beat Etiologies: ischemia; CMP; catecholaminergic torsades de pointes (TdP = â€œtwisting of the points,â€ PMVT + â†‘ QT): â†‘ QT acquired (meds, lytes, stroke, see â€œECGâ€) w/ risk â†‘ w/ â†“ HR, freq PVCs (pause dependent) or congenital (K/Na channelopathies) w/ resting Tw abnl & TdP triggered by sympathetic stimulation (eg, exercise, emotion, sudden loud noises) (Lancet 2008;372:750) Brugada syndrome (Na channelopathy; JACC 2018;72:1046): â™‚ > â™€; pseudo-RBBB w/ STE in V1â€“V3 (provoked w/ class IA or IC) on resting ECG

item.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica
item.description: Polymyalgia rheumatica (JAMA 2016;315:2442; Lancet 2017;390:1700) Prev 7/1000 of age â‰¥50. In 50% of GCA Pts; 15% of PMR Pts develop GCA.

item.title: Polyp or Tumor
item.description: Polyp or Tumor Typically slow ooze, p/w fatigue, weight loss, iron deficiency, anemia

item.title: polyps
item.description: polyps Pathophysiology & epidemiology (NEJM 2016;374:1065) Accumulation of mutations in colonic epithelial cell DNA affecting oncogenes & tumor suppressor genes â†’ tumor initiation (formation of adenoma; APC loss of fxn) â†’ tumor progression (adenoma â†’ carcinoma; K-ras gain of fxn, DCC, p53 loss of fxn) Risk factors: â†‘ age, FHx (sporadic in 1Â° relatives, Lynch, FAP), IBD, â†‘ dietary fat, central adiposity, â†‘ EtOH, â†“ fiber, â†‘ red meat, smoking, DM Protective factors: â†‘ physical activity, ASA/NSAIDs, Ca2+ intake, HRT, â†“ BMI; possibly â†‘ fiber, vitamin D, fish oil, statins, selenium Neoplastic polyps: adenomas (tubular, villous, tubulovillous dysplasia), sessile serrated adenomas/polyps (concern for interval CRC), carcinomas Non-neoplastic polyps: hyperplastic, juvenile, Peutz-Jeghers (can undergo malignant transformation), inflammatory [[CRC screening]]

item.title: polyuria
item.description: polyuria Definition and pathophysiology Polyuria defined as >3 L UOP per day Due to an osmotic or a water diuresis; almost always due to osmotic diuresis in inpatients Workup Perform a timed urine collection (6 h sufficient) and measure Uosm 24-h osmole excretion rate = 24-h UOP (actual or estimate) Ã— Uosm 1000 mOsm/d â†’ osmotic diuresis; <800 mOsm/d â†’ water diuresis

item.title: Portal HTN gastropathy
item.description: Portal HTN gastropathy â†‘ portal venous pressure â†’ ectatic vessels, hyperemia in gastric antrum. Rx: reduce portal HTN (octreotide), Î²B, TIPS.

item.title: Portal vein thrombosis PVT
item.description: Portal vein thrombosis (PVT) (Clin Liver Dis 2017;10:152; Gastro 2019;156:1582) Definition: thrombosis of portal vein often w/ extension into mesenteric vein/splenic vein Etiologies: commonly due to cirrhosis or hypercoaguable state (cancer, infection, OCP, collagen vascular diseases, BehÃ§etâ€™s, IBD, surgery, trauma, OCPs, preg) [[Clinical manifestations-Portal vein thrombosis (PVT)]] [[Dx-Portal vein thrombosis (PVT)]] [[Treatment-Portal vein thrombosis (PVT)]]

item.description: Prerenal acute kidney injury etiology â†“ Effective arterial volume (NEJM 2007;357:797) Hypovolemia, â†“ CO (CHF), â†“ oncotic pressure (cirrhosis, nephrotic), vasodilation (sepsis) Î” local renal perfusion: NSAIDs, ACEI/ARB, contrast, calcineurin inhib, HRS, hyperCa Large vessel: RAS (bilateral + ACEI), VTE, dissection, abd compart.

item.description: Prevention-Contrast-induced acute kidney injury consider if eGFR <60 (espec. w/ proteinuria) DM MI HoTN (CJASN 2013;8:1618) Prevention Isotonic IV fluids: may be helpful if high risk (Lancet 2017;389:1312) Outpatients: 3 mL/kg/h Ã— 1 h prior, 1â€“1.

item.title: Prevention-pneumonia
item.description: Prevention-pneumonia All persons >65 or age 19â€“64 w/ CHF, lung disease, cirrhosis, DM, EtOH, smoker, immunosupp. (eg, ESRD, organ transplant, HIV, leukemia, lymphoma, asplenia) PCV20 vaccine or PCV15 + PPSV23 1 yr later

item.title: Primary hyperparathyroidism
item.description: Primary hyperparathyroidism The serum level of parathyroid hormone, calcium, phosphorus, and 25-hydroxyvitamin D should be measured. Patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism usually have low-normal calcium and elevated parathyroid hormone.

item.title: Primary immune thrombocytopenic purpura ITP
item.description: Primary immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) (Blood 2010;115:168) Isolated thrombocytopenia due to immune plt destruction (auto-Ab to plts) & â†“ production (auto-Ab to megakaryocytes) without precipitant

item.title: Primary sclerosing cholangitis PSC
item.description: Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) (NEJM 2016;375:1161; Clin Liver Dis 2020;15:125) Diffuse inflammation of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts leading to fibrosis & stricturing of biliary system.

item.title: Principles of Imaging in Vasculitides
item.description: Principles of Imaging in Vasculitides for large- and certain medium-vessel vasculitides, various imaging techniques can be useful magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) or computed tomography angiography (CTA) allow for the assessment of extensive vascular territories vessels not readily accessible for tissue biopsy ultrasound, particularly color-coded duplex sonography, is often used as first-line imaging in patients with suspected giant cell arteritis (GCA) small-vessel vasculitides difficult to directly visualize with imaging indirect signs can be detected; this may play a role in evaluating disease activity and extent of involvement Reference - Curr Rheumatol Rep 2020 Jun 19;22(8):34

item.title: Principles of treatment-asthma
item.description: Principles of treatment-asthma Education and avoidance of environmental triggers (Lancet 2015;386:1075); yearly flu shot Use quick-relief rescue medication as needed for all Pts

item.title: Principles-solitary pulmonary nodule
item.description: Principles-solitary pulmonary nodule Definition: single, well-defined, <3 cm, surrounded by nl lung, no LAN or pleural effusion Often â€œincidentalomas,â€ esp with â†‘ CT use, but may still be early, curable malignancy

item.title: Prinzmetal's variant angina
item.description: Prinzmetal’s variant angina Coronary spasm â†’ transient STE usually w/o MI (but MI, AVB, VT can occur) Pts usually young, smokers Â± other vasospastic disorders (eg, migraines, Raynaudâ€™s) Angiography: nonobstructive CAD (spasm can be provoked during cath but rarely done) [[Treatment of Prinzmetals variant angina]] Cocaine-induced vasospasm: CCB, nitrates, ASA; ?

item.description: Procainamide 10-15 mg/kg IV n/a decrease BP: 1 QT:Â± AVN blocker % Backlink: [[Antiarrhythmic Drugs (AAD) for AF]]

item.description: Procedures-Endocarditis Prophylaxis Dental: manipulation of gingival tissue or periapical region of teeth or perf oral mucosa (eg, extraction, periodontal, implant, root canal, cleaning)

item.title: Prognosis-acute liver failure
item.description: Prognosis-acute liver failure (Ann Intern Med 2016;164:724; World J Gastro 2016;22:1523) Non-acetaminophen ALF mortality ~70%, acetaminophen-induced ALF mortality ~25â€“30%

item.title: Prognosis-acute pancreatitis
item.description: Prognosis-acute pancreatitis (NEJM 2016;375:1972) Ransonâ€™s, APACHE II: predict severity at 48 h using multiple physiolog. criteria; poor PPV

item.title: Prognosis-Alcohol-associated hepatitis
item.description: Prognosis-Alcohol-associated hepatitis scoring systems include Maddreyâ€™s discriminant fxn (MDF), Lille model, MELD MDF (4.6 Ã— [PT â€“ control] + Tb) â‰¥32 w/ 30â€“50% 1-mo mortality if unRxâ€™d (Gastro 1996;110:1847)

item.title: Prognosis-cirrhosis
item.description: Prognosis-cirrhosis ( www.mdcalc.com/child-pugh-score-cirrhosis-mortality) Modified Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CPS) score based on ascites, enceph., & labs (bili, alb & INR; see Appendix).

item.title: Prognosis-pulmonary hypertension
item.description: Prognosis-pulmonary hypertension Median survival after dx ~2.8 y; PAH (all etiologies): 2-y 66%, 5-y 48% (Chest 2004;126:78â€“S) Poor prognostic factors: clinical evidence of RV failure, rapidly progressive sx, WHO (modified NYHA) class IV, 6MWT <300 m, peak VO2 <10.

item.title: Prognosis-syncope
item.description: Prognosis-syncope (Ann Emerg Med 1997;29:459; NEJM 2002;347:878) 22% overall recurrence rate if idiopathic, else 3% recurrence Cardiac syncope has poor prognosis (20â€“40% 1-y SCD rate); vasovagal good prognosis Unexplained syncope w/ 1.

item.title: Prognosis-ulcerative colitis
item.description: Prognosis-ulcerative colitis 50% in remission at any given time. Intermittent exacerbations in 90%; continual active disease in ~18%. Prox progression in 25% at 10 y.

item.title: Prolonged-QT-interval
item.description: Prolonged-QT-interval Prolonged QT interval (NEJM 2008;358:169; www.torsades.org) Measure QT using threshold method (start of QRS to end of Tw at isoelectric line) or tangent (QRS to where tangent of Tw downslope intersects baseline) when long tail.

item.title: Propafenone
item.description: Propafenone 600 mg PO x 150-300mg tid n/a [[Flecainide]] % Backlink: [[Antiarrhythmic Drugs (AAD) for AF]]

item.description: Prophylaxis-HIV AIDS (NEJM 2015;373:2237; Lancet 2016;387:53; J Infect Dis 2018;218:16; CDC 2021) Pre-exposure (PrEP): TDF/FTC daily, â†“ transmission >90% if adherent.

item.title: prostate cancer
item.description: prostate cancer Epidemiology and risk factors (NEJM 2003;349:366) Most common cancer in U.S. men; 2nd most common cause of cancer death in men Lifetime risk of prostate cancer dx ~16%; lifetime risk of dying of prostate cancer ~3% â†‘ risk with â†‘ age (rare if <45 y), in African Americans, âŠ• FHx, BRCA mutations Clinical manifestations Most prostate cancers (78%) are asymptomatic and localized at diagnosis Metastatic dis.

item.title: Rate of correction of hypernatremia
item.description: Rate of correction of hypernatremia depends on acuity of onset and risk: chronic (>48 hr): ~12 mEq/d appears safe w/o risk of cerebral edema (CJASN 2019;14:656)

item.title: Rationale PA catheter and tailored therapy
item.description: Rationale PA catheter and tailored therapy Cardiac output (CO) = SV Ã— HR; optimize SV (and thereby CO) by manipulating preload/ LVEDV (w/ IVF, diuretics), contractility (w/ inotropes), & afterload (w/ vasodilators)

item.title: Raynaud phenomenon
item.description: Raynaud phenomenon a problem that causes decreased blood flow to the fingers. In some cases, it also causes less blood flow to the ears, toes, nipples, knees, or nose.

item.title: RB-ILD resp bronchiolitis-assoc ILD
item.description: RB-ILD resp bronchiolitis-assoc ILD Bronchial thickening, centrilobular nodules, patchy ground-glass opacities; upper lobe predom. MÏ† in alveoli.

item.title: Recognizing and managing comorbidities of Migraine
item.description: Recognizing and managing comorbidities of Migraine Identify comorbid conditions Select drugs and adjust their use according to comorbidities present Alleviate comborbidities if possible to improve outcome

item.title: Recommended Chronic Therapy by HF Stage
item.description: Recommended Chronic Therapy by HF Stage (JACC 2021;77:772) Utility of BNP-guided Rx (inPt and outPt) remains debated (Eur Heart J 2014;35:16) Implantable PA pressure sensor in sx Pts: ~19â€“37% â†“ risk of hosp (Lancet 2016;387:453 & 2021;398:991) Stage (not NYHA Class) Therapy A At risk for HF (eg, HTN); but asx & w/o struct.

item.title: Recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral DAA Regimens
item.description: Recommended First-Line Oral Direct-Acting Antiviral (DAA) Regimens Sofosbuvir & velpatasvir Genotypes 1â€“6, 12 weeks Rx Glecaprevir & pibrentasvir Gentotypes 1â€“6; 8 weeks Rx Simplified treatment: adults w/ HCV w/o cirrhosis or w/ compensated cirrhosis & no prior HCV treatment; cannot have HIV, HBsAg âŠ•, pregnancy, HCC, ESRD, or liver transplant; if decompensated or previously treated, refer to GI for assistance.

item.title: Recurrent infection-clostridioides difficile infection
item.description: Recurrent infection-clostridioides difficile infection (15â€“30% risk after d/c of abx, most w/in 2 wk of stopping abx) 1st recurrence: fidaxomicin 200 mg PO bid Ã— 10 d or vanco 125 mg PO q6h Ã— 10â€“14 d.

item.title: Refractory ascites
item.description: Refractory ascites seen in 5â€“10% of Pts; 2-y survival 25% Defined as [[diuretic-resistant]] if on 2-g Na diet w/ minimal weight loss on max diuretics, or diuretic-induced complications (AKI, Na <125, â†‘ K, encephalopathy) Conflicting evid.

item.description: Renal losses of Hypovolemic-hypotonic-hyponatremia (UNa >20 mEq/L, FENa >1%): diuretics (esp. thiazides, because loop diuretics â†“ tonicity of medullary interstitium, Î” for H2O absorption, & âˆ´ urine concentrating ability), salt-wasting nephropathy, cerebral salt wasting, mineralocorticoid deficiency

item.title: Renal tubular acidoses
item.description: Renal tubular acidoses (RTAs) (Adv Ther 2021;38:949) (Adv Ther 2021;38:949) Proximal (Type II): â†“ proximal reabsorption of HCO3 1Â° (Fanconiâ€™s syndrome) = â†“ proximal reabsorption of HCO3, PO4, glc, amino acids Acquired: paraprotein (MM, amyloidosis), metals (Pb, Cd, Hg, Cu), â†“ vit D, PNH, renal Tx Meds: acetazolamide, aminoglycosides, ifosfamide, cisplatin, topiramate, tenofovir Distal (Type I): defective distal H+ secretion 1Â°, autoimmune (SjÃ¶grenâ€™s, RA, SLE), hypercalciuria, meds (ampho, Li, ifosfamide); normally a/w â†“ K; if with â†‘ K â†’ sickle cell, obstruction, renal transplant Hypoaldo (Type IV): hypoaldo â†’ â†‘ K â†’ â†“ NH3 synthesis â†’ â†“ urine acid-carrying capacity â†“ renin: diabetic nephropathy, NSAIDs, chronic interstitial nephritis, calcineurin inh, HIV â†“ aldo production: 1Â° AI, ACEI/ARBs, heparin, severe illness, inherited (â†“ 21-hydroxylase) â†“ response to aldosterone Meds: K-sparing diuretics, TMP-SMX, pentamidine, calcineurin inhibitors Tubulointerstitial disease: sickle cell, SLE, amyloid, DM

item.description: Renal-limited vasculitis Small vessel pauci-immune vasculitis causing RPGN w/o other organ involvement Dx studies: 80% âŠ• ANCA (MPO >PR3); biopsy with pauci-immune GN Â± granulomas Treatment identical to that for GPA/MPA

item.title: renal-Secondary Causes of Hypertension
item.description: renal-Secondary Causes of Hypertension Renal parenchymal (2â€“3%) h/o DM, polycystic kidney disease, glomerulonephritis CrCl, albuminuria See â€œKidney Diseaseâ€ Renovascular (1â€“2%) Athero (90%) FMD (10%, young women) PAN, scleroderma ARF induced by ACEI/ARB Recurrent flash pulm edema Renal bruit; hypokalemia (NEJM 2009;361:1972) MRA (>90% Se & Sp, less for FMD), CTA, duplex U/S, angio, plasma renin (low Sp)

item.description: Replace free H2O deficit (also replace concurrent volume deficit if appropriate): eg, 1 L D5W given to 70-kg man w/ [Na] = 160 mEq/L will â†“ [Na]serum by 3.

item.description: Replacement fluid of continuous veno-venous hemofiltration Choice of replacement fluid buffer: HCO3 (+ heparin to prevent clotting, although can be run heparin-free)

item.title: Residual syndrome
item.description: Residual syndrome Inadequate removal of uremic toxins through conventional dialysis may result in a phenomenon known as residual syndrome. Patients with this syndrome may experience subtle signs of malnutrition, mild lethargy, infection, and serositis

item.title: Resistant HTN
item.description: Resistant HTN (BP >goal on â‰¥3 drugs incl diuretic; HTN 2018;72:e53) Exclude: 2Â° causes (see table) and pseudoresistance: inaccurate measure (cuff size), diet noncomp (â†‘ Na), poor Rx compliance/dosing, white coat HTN (âœ“ ABPM) Ensure effective diuresis (chlorthalidone or indapamide >HCTZ; loop >thiazide if eGFR <30) Can add aldosterone antagonist (Lancet 2015;386:2059), Î²-blocker (particularly vasodilators such as carvedilol, labetalol, or nebivolol), Î±-blocker, or direct vasodilator Consider renal denervation therapy (Lancet 2018;391:2346; 2021;397:2476)

item.title: respiratory-alkalosis
item.description: respiratory-alkalosis Etiologies (NEJM 2002;347:43; Crit Care 2010;14:220) Hypoxia â†’ hyperventilation: pneumonia, CHF, PE, restrictive lung disease, anemia Primary hyperventilation CNS stimulation, pain, anxiety, trauma, stroke, CNS infection, pontine tumors drugs: salicylates toxicity (early), Î²-agonists, progesterone, methylxanthines, nicotine pregnancy, sepsis, hepatic failure, hyperthyroidism, fever Pseudorespiratory alkalosis: â†“ perfusion w/ preserved ventilation (eg, CPR, severe HoTN) â†’ â†“ delivery of CO2 to lungs for excretion; low PaCO2 but â†‘ tissue CO2

item.title: Rhabdomyolysis
item.description: Rhabdomyolysis (NEJM 2009;361:62) Pathophys: myoglobin-induced oxidant injury, vasoconstriction, myoglobin precipitation & pre-renal (extravasation). Can lead to â†“ Ca, â†‘ K, and â†‘ PO4.

item.title: Right-ventricular-hypertrophy
item.description: Right-ventricular-hypertrophy Etiologies: cor pulmonale, congenital (tetralogy of Fallot, TGA, PS, ASD, VSD), MS, TR Criteria [all insensitive, but specific (except in COPD); all w/ poor PPV in general population]

item.title: risk factor of delirium
item.description: risk factor of delirium older aged >65 baseline cognitive dysfunction preexisting hearing and visual impairment, as well as indices for poor overall health, including baseline immobility, malnutrition, and underlying medical or neurologic illness.

item.title: Risk Factors and Screening
item.description: Risk Factors and Screening High risk: >10 lifetime sexual partners, prior STI, MSM, sex workers Screening recommendations: differ based on sexual practices and risk.

item.title: Risk factors for bloodstream infections
item.description: Risk factors for bloodstream infections (JAMA 2012;308:502; CID;2020;71) Syndromes with high likelihood of bacteremia: Sepsis Endovascular infxns: endocarditis, infection of pacemaker, vascular graft or IV catheter [[vertebral osteomyelitis]], epidural abscess, septic arthritis Risk factors: indwelling lines, IVDU, immunosupp.

item.title: Risk factors-acute aortic syndromes
item.description: Risk factors-acute aortic syndromes (Lancet 2015;385:800) Classic (in older Pts): HTN (h/o HTN in >70% of dissections); age (60sâ€“70s), sex (~65% â™‚); smoking; â†‘ lipids.

item.title: Risk Factors-bacterial endocarditis
item.description: Risk Factors-bacterial endocarditis Abnormal valve (JAMA 1997;277:1794; JACC 2018;72:2443) High risk: prior endocarditis, prosthetic valve or ring, some congenital heart disease (unrepaired cyanotic; shunt/conduit; prosthesis in past 6 mos), transplant heart, valvulopathy, VAD Medium risk previous rheumatic fever non-rheumatic valve disease (including MVP w/ MR or thickened leaflet), HCM bicuspid AoV Risk of bacteremia: IVDU indwelling venous catheters, hemodialysis, prosthetic material in heart (eg, pacemaker, ICD, graft), poor dentition

item.title: Risk factors-venous thromboembolism
item.description: Risk factors-venous thromboembolism [[Virchowâ€™s triad]] for thrombogenesis. Malignancy (12% of â€œidiopathicâ€ DVT/PE; Circ 2013;128:2614) [[Venous Thromboembolism and Cancer]] History of thrombosis

item.description: Risk stratification of fever and neutropenia History: outPt, ECOG 0â€“1, age <60 y, solid tumor, no sx, no major comorbidities, no h/o fungal infection, MASCC Risk Index â‰¥21 (Support Care Cancer 2013;21:1487) Exam: temp <39 Â°C, no tachypnea, no HoTN, no Î” MS, no dehydration Labs: ANC >100 cells/ÂµL, anticipated duration of neutropenia â‰¤100 cells/ÂµL <7 d

item.description: Role of Circulating Tumor DNA in Guiding Adjuvant Therapy in Colon Cancer Adjuvant chemotherapy after resection of stage III colon cancer appears to improve outcomes, but many patients are treated to benefit a few.

item.title: Role of hematopoietic growth factors
item.description: Role of hematopoietic growth factors Granulocyte (G-CSF) and granulocyte-macrophage (GM-CSF) colony-stimulating factors can be used (but not in AML) as 1Â° Ppx when expected FN incidence >20% or as 2Â° Ppx after FN has occurred in a prior cycle (to maintain dose-intensity for curable tumors) CSFs â†“ rate of FN but have not been shown to affect mortality (Cochrane 2014 CD003039)

item.description: Rule out mimickers of ILD Congestive heart failure (âœ“ BNP, trial of diuresis); infection: viral, atypical bacterial; malignancy: lymphangitic carcinomatosis, bronchoalveolar, leukemia, lymphoma

item.description: Rx-Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) Obeticholic acid (FXR agonist): monoRx if cannot tolerate UDCA (but not in decompen cirrhosis) or if no Î” w/ UDCA after 1 y; found to â†“ AÏ†, â†‘ pruritus (NEJM 2016;375:631) ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) (13â€“15 mg/kg bid), monitor for 3â€“6 mos â†’ ~25% complete response, â†‘ survival & â†“ histologic change & â†“ complications (varices).

item.description: Sarcoidosis (AJRCCM 2020;201:e26; JAMA 2022;327:856) Prevalence: African Americans, northern Europeans, and females; onset in 3rd-5th decade Pathophysiology: depression of cellular immune system peripherally, activation centrally

item.title: SCLC staging and treatment
item.description: SCLC staging and treatment SCLC usually disseminated at presentation; poor overall survival Can be very responsive to chemotherapy, but rapidly develop resistance Diagnosis: all have Rb & p53 mutations (Nature 2015;524:47); 90% w/ neuroendo markers Treatment: primarily chemo (platinum + etoposide); adding anti-[[PD-L1]] Ab [[atezolizumab]] â†‘ survival (NEJM 2018;379:2220), as does concurrent thoracic RT in limited-stage disease Prophylactic cranial irradiation (PCI) controversial.

item.title: Scleroderma renal crisis
item.description: Scleroderma renal crisis (Nature Neph 2016;12:678) 5â€“20% diffuse cutaneous SSc w/ narrowing glomerular vessels. Sx: renal failure, severe HTN, encephalopathy.

item.description: Screening and Diagnosis-HIV AIDS (JAMA 2018;320:379) Screen all 13â€“64 yo at least once, every preg, if new STI dx; screen high risk annually HIV Ab/p24Ag (ELISA assay): âŠ• 1â€“12 wk after acute infxn; >99% Se; 1Â° screening test If âŠ•, Ab differentiation assay confirms and differentiates HIV-1 vs.

item.title: Screening for latent TB
item.description: Screening for latent TB Whom to screen: high likelihood of exposure and/or high risk of progression to active disease including HIV âŠ• and prior to immunosuppression (pre-transplant or anti-TNF) Relies on host immune system, so limited Se in immunosuppressed individuals Nb, testing for host exposure & immune response to TB, not whether TB active (vide infra) Screening tests IFN-Î³ release assays (IGRA): preferred test; Ag-stimulated IFN-Î³ release from Ptâ€™s T-cells.

item.title: sensible and insensible fluid losses
item.description: sensible and insensible fluid losses Insensible losses (nonmeasurable) Lungs: 200 mL Skin: 600 mL Sweat: Variable Sensible losses (measurable) Fecal: 200 mL Urine: 800 to 1500 mL These losses account for 2000 to 2500 mL/day, giving a 24-hour fluid requirement of 30 to 35 mL/kg to maintain normal fluid balance.

item.description: Sequential management of bacterial meningitis Blood cx, initiate empiric antibiotics, consider corticosteroids (vide infra) CT head if indicated (see below) LP ASAP (if not contraindicated); yield of CSF cx unlikely to be changed if obtained w/in ~4 h of initiation of abx Diagnostic studies (NEJM 2017;388:3036) Blood cultures Ã—2 before abx WBC count: >10,000 in >90% of bacterial meningitis in healthy hosts Head CT to r/o mass effect before LP if â‰¥1 high-risk feature: immunosupp.

item.title: Stepwise Evaluation of a Patient with Delirium
item.description: Stepwise Evaluation of a Patient with Delirium from Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e Initial Evaluation History with special attention to medications (including over-the-counter and herbals) General physical examination and neurologic examination Complete blood count Electrolyte panel including calcium, magnesium, phosphorus Liver function tests, including albumin Renal function tests First-Tier Further Evaluation Guided by Initial Evaluation Systemic infection screen - Urinalysis and culture - Chest radiograph - Blood cultures Electrocardiogram Arterial blood gas Serum and/or urine toxicology screen (perform earlier in young persons) Brain imaging with MRI with diffusion and gadolinium (preferred) or CT Suspected CNS infection or other inflammatory disorder: [[lumbar puncture after brain imaging]] Suspected seizure-related etiology: electroencephalogram (EEG) (if high suspicion, should be performed immediately)

item.title: Transcellular shifts-hyperkalemia
item.description: Transcellular shifts-hyperkalemia (BMJ 2009;339:1019) Acidemia, â†“ insulin (DM), cell lysis (tumor, rhabdo, ischemic bowel, hemolysis, transfusions, resorbing hematomas, hyperthermia, rewarming), hyperkalemic periodic paralysis, â†‘ osmolality.

item.title: Transfusion reactions
item.description: Transfusion reactions Reason why blood products (unless massive txfusion) run 1 at a time. For all rxns (except minor allergic): stop txfusion; send remaining blood product + fresh blood draw to blood bank.

item.title: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload
item.description: Transfusion-associated circulatory overload : â†‘ volume â†’ pulm. edema, â†‘ BP. Rx: slow transfusion rate, diuretics, O2, Â± nitrates, Â± positive pressure ventilation.

item.title: transfusion-related acute lung injury
item.description: transfusion-related acute lung injury : non-cardiogenic pulm. edema due to donor allo-Abs (from multiparous â™€ plasma) binding recipient WBCs, which then aggregate in pulmonary vasculature and release mediators causing â†‘ capillary permeability.

item.title: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt TIPS
item.description: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) (Gastro 2017;152:157) â†“ ascites in 75%; â†‘ CrCl, â†‘ enceph, survival benefit over LVP remains controversial Contraindic: grade II enceph, CHF or pulm HTN, active infxn or biliary obstruction Complications: bleeding, fistula; stent thrombosis (1-y patency w/ coated stents ~80%); infxn (â€œendotipsitisâ€); new or â†‘ enceph in 20â€“30% (Am J Gastro 2016;111:523), hemolysis Consider for liver transplant if above fail

item.description: transthoracic echo vs transesophageal echo in-Diagnosis-bacterial endocarditis NVE PVE Abscess Transthoracic (TTE) 39â€“58% 33% 18â€“63% Transesophageal (TEE) >90% 86% 76â€“100% (Mayo Clin Proc 2014;89:799; Circ 2015;132:1435; Eur Radiol 2015; 25:2125; J Am Soc Echo 2016;29:315)

item.title: Transudates
item.description: Transudates Congestive heart failure (40%): 80% bilateral, Â± cardiomegaly on CXR occasionally exudative (especially after aggressive diuresis or if chronic) Constrictive pericarditis (knock on exam, calcification or thickening on imaging) Cirrhosis (â€œhepatic hydrothoraxâ€): diaphragmatic pores allow passage of ascitic fluid often right-sided (Â²âˆ•Â³) & massive (even witho marked ascites) Nephrotic syndrome: usually small, bilateral, asymptomatic (r/o PE b/c hypercoag) Other: PE (usually exudate), malignancy (lymphatic obstruction), myxedema, CAPD

item.title: Treatment gastroesophageal reflux disease
item.description: Treatment [[gastroesophageal reflux disease]] (World J Gastrointest Endosc 2018;10:175; Am J Gastro 2022;117:27) Lifestyle: avoid precipitants, lose weight, no eating 2 hrs before bed, exercise, Ã˜ tobacco

item.title: treatment gastroesophageal reflux disease
item.description: treatment gastroesophageal reflux disease (World J Gastrointest Endosc 2018;10:175; Am J Gastro 2022;117:27) Lifestyle: avoid precipitants, lose weight, no eating 2 hrs before bed, exercise, Ã˜ tobacco Medical: start low-dose PPI, uptitrate up to 40 mg bid; H2 blockers for intermittent sx Refractory (max dose â‰¥8 wks): confirm w/ pH testing on or off PPI, consider hernia repair If acidic or sx correlate w/ reflux episodes: surgical fundoplication (emerging Rx: LES sphincter augmentation w/ radiofrequency, implantable magnetic or electrical devices) If nl pH or no sx correlation = â€œfxnal dyspepsiaâ€ (Gastro 2020;158:2286); Rx w/ TCA, SSRI

item.title: Treatment of active tuberculosis
item.description: Treatment of active tuberculosis (NEJM 2015;373:2149; Lancet 2016;387:1211) Prior to treatment, consult ID, check LFTs, Cr, HIV & hepatitis A/B/C screen, DM screen, pregnancy screen, vision testing for acuity and color, EtOH use history Treatment requires several drugs to prevent resistance (see below) Suspect MDR TB if prior TB Rx (esp.

item.title: Treatment of acute advanced heart failure
item.description: Treatment of acute advanced heart failure (Circ 2013;128:e240) Consider PAC if not resp to Rx, unsure re: vol status, HoTN, hypoperfusion, need inotropes

item.title: treatment of acute decompensating heart failure
item.description: treatment of acute decompensating heart failure (NEJM 2017;377:1964) Assess congestion & adequacy of perfusion For congestion: â€œLMNOPâ€ Lasix IV; 1â€“2.

item.title: Treatment of Alchololic-associated hepatitis
item.description: Treatment of Alchololic-associated hepatitis consider if MDF â‰¥32, MELD >18, or presence of encephalopathy Glucocorticoids (eg, methylprednisolone 32 mg/d or prednisolone 40 mg/d Ã— 4 wk â†’ 4â€“6 wk taper) may â†“ 1-mo but not 6-mo mortality, a/w â†‘ infection (NEJM 2015;372:1619, CD001511)

item.title: Treatment of Antiphospholipid syndrome
item.description: Treatment of Antiphospholipid syndrome UFH/LMWH â†’ warfarin (lifelong for most Pts) Rivaroxaban inferior to warfarin in triple positive (âŠ• ACL, LA, & Î²2-GP) (Blood 2018;132:1365)

item.title: Treatment of asymptomatic 1Â° HPT
item.description: Treatment of asymptomatic 1Â° HPT Surgery if: age <50 y; serum Ca >1 mg/dL >ULN; CrCl <60 mL/min, DEXA T score <â€“2.
