item.description: Treatment of BehÃ§etâ€™s syndrome Mucocutaneous: Mild: topical steroids, colchicine (esp. for erythema nodosum), dapsone, apremilast (PDE-4 inhib) for oral ulcers and ?

item.title: Treatment of Chronic HF with Reduced EF
item.description: Treatment of Chronic HF with Reduced EF (Circ 2017;136:e137; JACC 2021;77:772) Diuretics | Loop Â± thiazides diuretics (sx relief; no mortality benefit) [[RASi ACEI ARB]] [[Î²-blocker]] [[Aldosterone-antagonists]] [[SGLT2i]] [[Hydralazine—nitrates]] [[Ivabradine]] (If blocker w/o âŠ– ino) [[Digoxin]] [[Vericiguat]] [[Cardiac-resynch-therapy]] (CRT, qv) [[ICD]] (see â€œCardiac Rhythm Mgmt Devicesâ€) [[Iron-supplementation]] [[Anticoagulation-Treatment of Chronic HF with Reduced EF]] Heart rhythm If AF & NYHA IIâ€“IV w/ EF <35%, catheter ablation â†“ D/HF hosp vs.

item.title: Treatment of Constipation
item.description: Treatment of Constipation 1st line â†‘ fluid, fiber, exercise; emollient laxative (docusate) to soften stool. 2nd line: Bulk laxatives (psyllium, methylcellulose) to â†‘ colonic residue, â†‘ peristalsis.

item.title: Treatment of Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
item.description: Treatment of Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis (Blood 2017;129:289; J Inflamm Res 2017;10:49): Rx underlying disorder. Heme malig â†’ chemoradiation; HCV â†’ antivirals; CTD â†’ DMARD/steroids Â± RTX.

item.title: Treatment of Cushingâ€™s syndrome
item.description: Treatment of Cushingâ€™s syndrome (JCEM 2015;100:2807. J Intern Med 2019;286:526) Surgical: * resection of pituitary adenoma, adrenal tumor or ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor, or bilateral surgical adrenalectomy if unable to control source of ACTH Medical: [[ketoconazole]] [[metyrapone]] [[osilodrostat]] [[cabergoline]] [[pasireotide]] mitotane to â†“ cortisol, and/or mifepristone to block cortisol action at glucocorticoid receptor frequently used as bridge to surgery or when surgery contraindicated Radiation: can do pituitary XRT, but not effective immediately (takes 6 mo to 2 y) Glucocorticoid replacement therapy Ã— 6â€“36 mo after TSS (lifelong glucocorticoid + mineralocorticoid replacement if medical or surgical adrenalectomy)

item.title: Treatment of DKA
item.description: Treatment of DKA (BMJ 2019;365:1114) R/o possible precipitants Infection, intra-abdominal process, MI, etc. (see above) Aggressive hydration 1L NS then ~250 cc/hr, tailor to dehydration & CV status Insulin 0.

item.title: Treatment of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
item.description: Treatment of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis assess severity w/ BVAS/GPA score (Arth Rheum Dis 2009;68:1827) same as [[Microscopic polyangiitis.md]] Mild disease (no end-organ dysfxn; BVAS 0â€“3): MTX + steroids (Arth Rheum 2012;64:3472)

item.title: Treatment of Heart failure with preserved EF
item.description: Treatment of Heart failure with preserved EF diuresis, Rx HTN, tachycardia, and ischemia SGLT2i â†“ CV death or HF hosp (NEJM 2021;385:1451; DELIVER)

item.title: Treatment of Hemochromatosis
item.description: Treatment of Hemochromatosis phlebotomy (250 mL = 1 unit, ~250 mg of Fe) qwk until Fe sat <50% & ferritin 50â€“100 Âµg/L, then q3â€“4mo; PPI â†“ intestinal Fe absorption & may â†“ need for phlebotomy; avoid vit C & uncooked seafood; deferoxamine if phleb.

item.title: Treatment of HIT
item.description: Treatment of HIT (NEJM 2015;373:252; Blood Adv 2018;2:3360) Discontinue heparin (incl. flushes, LMWH Ppx, heparin lines). Avoid plts (anecdotal link w/ thrombosis); if given warfarin, give vit K to reverse, prevent warfarin skin necrosis.

item.title: Treatment of Hyperkalemia-hyperkalemia
item.description: Treatment of Hyperkalemia-hyperkalemia [[Ca gluconate Ca chloride]] 1â€“2 amps IV onset <3 min with Transient effect (30â€“60 min) Stabilizes cell membrane CaCl contains more calcium and is typically reserved for codes (â†‘ risk of tissue necrosis) or via central line

item.title: Treatment of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
item.description: Treatment of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Circ 2020;142:e558; Lancet 2021;398:2102; JACC 2022;79:390) Heart failure âŠ– inotropes/chronotropes: Î²-blockers (JACC 2021;78:2505), CCB (verapamil), disopyramide

item.title: Treatment of Hypervolemic hyponatremia
item.description: Treatment of Hypervolemic hyponatremia free water restrict (1st line), diurese w/ loop diuretics (avoid thiazides) & â†‘ EAV (vasodilators to â†‘ CO in CHF, colloid infusion in cirrhosis)

item.title: Treatment of Hypovolemic hyponatremia
item.description: Treatment of Hypovolemic hyponatremia volume repletion with isotonic 0.9% saline at a slow rate. Once volume replete â†’ stimulus for ADH removed (w/ very short ADH tÂ½) â†’ kidneys excrete free H2O â†’ serum Na will correct rapidly (D5W Â± dDAVP if overcorrection)

item.title: Treatment of latent TB
item.description: Treatment of latent TB If screening test âŠ• and no risk factors, confirm prior to treatment; if âŠ• w/ risk factors, proceed to treatment (CID 2017;64:11).

item.title: Treatment of LDL-C
item.description: Treatment of LDL-C Statins: every 1 mmol (39 mg/dL) â†“ LDL-C â†’ 22% â†“ major vascular events (CV death, MI, stroke, revasc) in individuals w/ & w/o CAD (Lancet 2010;376:1670) Ezetimibe: â†“ major vascular events incl MI & stroke when added to statin post-ACS, w/ magnitude of benefit consistent w/ LDL-statin relationship (IMPROVE-IT, NEJM 2015;372:2387) PCSK9 inhibitors: ~60% â†“ LDL-C on top of statin, as monoRx, and in FH (EHJ 2014;35:2249); â†“ CV outcomes (NEJM 2017;376:1713 & 2018;379:2097) In homozygous FH: apheresis; evinacumab (ANGPTL3 inhib) â†“ LDL-C by ~50% (NEJM 2020;383:711)

item.title: Treatment of Migraine
item.description: Treatment of Migraine Abortive Rx: 5-HT1 agonists (triptans) effective if given early in migraine attack; Abortive: The goal of abortive treatment is to stop a migraine once it starts.

item.title: Treatment of other lipid fractions
item.description: Treatment of other lipid fractions HDL-C: low levels a/w â†‘ risk of MI, but no clinical benefit shown by raising Triglycerides: reasonable to treat levels >500 mg/dL w/ fibrates or Î©-3 FA to â†“ risk of pancreatitis.

item.title: Treatment of overt hypothyroidism
item.description: Treatment of overt hypothyroidism Levothyroxine (1.5â€“1.7 Âµg/kg/d), re âœ“ TSH q5â€“6wk, titrate q8-12 wks if TSH not in range Lower starting dose (0.

item.title: treatment of peptic ulcer disease
item.description: treatment of peptic ulcer disease (Lancet 2016;388:2355; Gastro 2016;151:51; Gut 2017;66:6; AJG 2017;112:212) If H. pylori âŠ• â†’ eradicate (â€œtest and treatâ€); if âŠ– â†’ gastric acid suppression w/ PPI 1st line: Quad.

item.title: Treatment of pericarditis
item.description: Treatment of pericarditis High-dose NSAID (eg, ibuprofen 600â€“800 mg tid) or ASA (eg, 650â€“1000 mg tid) Ã— 7â€“14 d then taper over wks; ASA preferred over NSAID in acute MI; consider PPI to â†“ risk of GIB Add colchicine 0.

item.title: Treatment of Prinzmetals variant angina
item.description: Treatment of Prinzmetals variant angina high-dose CCB & standing nitrates (+SL prn), ? Î±-blockers/statins; d/c smoking; avoid high-dose ASA (can inhibit prostacyclin and worsen spasm), nonselect Î²B, triptans

item.title: Treatment of SIADH
item.description: Treatment of SIADH (NEJM 2007;356:2064; AJKD 2020;76:203): fluid restrict + treat underlying cause hypertonic saline (Â± loop diuretic; AJKD 2020;76:203) if sx or Na fails to â†‘ w/ fluid restriction Intermittent bolus of 3% saline (~2 mL/kg q6h) vs.

item.title: Treatment of SVT
item.description: Treatment of SVT Rhythm Acute Treatment Long-term Treatment Unstable Acute: Cardioversion per ACLS n/a ST Acute: Treat underlying stressor(s) Long-term: n/a

item.title: Treatment of Thyroid storm
item.description: Treatment of Thyroid storm Î²-blocker, PTU or methimazole, iopanoic acid or iodide (for [[Wolff-Chaikoff effect]]) >1 h after PTU, Â± steroids (â†“ T4 â†’ T3)

item.title: Treatment of UTIs
item.description: Treatment of UTIs Scenario Empiric Treatment Guidelines (narrow based on UCx) Asymptomatic bacteruria Do not treat. Exceptions: pregnant women, renal transplant, prophylaxis prior to invasive urologic procedures (CID 2019;68:1611).

item.title: Treatment peptic ulcer disease
item.description: Treatment peptic ulcer disease (Lancet 2016;388:2355; Gastro 2016;151:51; Gut 2017;66:6; AJG 2017;112:212) If H. pylori âŠ• â†’ eradicate (â€œtest and treatâ€); if âŠ– â†’ gastric acid suppression w/ PPI 1st line: Quad.

item.title: Treatment prevention-herpes zoster
item.description: Treatment prevention-herpes zoster Uncomplicated: acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir x 7 d; initiate w/in 72 h of onset for greatest benefit; consider after 72 h if new lesions present; minimal benefit after crusting Superimposed bacterial cellulitis is common; if suspected, treat with appropriate antibiotics Disseminated/immunosupp.

item.title: Treatment-accessory pathways wolff-parkinson-white
item.description: Treatment-accessory pathways (wolff-parkinson-white) (Heart Rhythm 2012;9:1006, Circ 2014;130:e199 & 2016;133:e506) AVRT (orthodromic): vagal, Î²B, CCB; care w/ adenosine (can precip AF); have defib ready AF/AFL w/ conduction down accessory pathway: need to Rx arrhythmia and â†‘ pathway refractoriness.

item.title: Treatment-Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity
item.description: Treatment-Acetaminophen hepatotoxicity NG lavage, activated charcoal if w/in 4 h. Consider early transfer to transplant ctr N-acetylcysteine: administer up to 72 h after ingestion, if time of ingestion unknown or chronic ingestion >4g/d; low threshold to start NAC w/ low or undetectable APAP levels

item.title: Treatment-acute aortic syndromes
item.description: Treatment-acute aortic syndromes (Circ 2010;121:1544; EHJ 2018;39:739; JACC 2019;74:1494 & 2020;76:1703) â†“ dP/dt targeting HR <60 & central BP <120 (or lowest that preserves perfusion; r/o pseudohypotension, eg, arm BP â†“ due to subclavian dissection; use highest BP reading) First IV Î²B (eg, esmolol, labetalol) to blunt reflex â†‘ HR & inotropy in response to vasodilators; verapamil/diltiazem if Î²B contraindic; then â†“ SBP w/ IV vasodilators (eg, nitroprusside) If HoTN: urgent surgical consult, IVF to achieve euvolemia, pressors to keep MAP 60-65 mmHg; r/o complication (eg, tamponade, contained rupture, severe AI) Proximal: surgery considered in all acute and in chronic if c/b progression, AI or aneurysm Distal: med Rx unless complication (see below) or favorable TEVAR anatomy w/ high-risk imaging features (JACC 2019;74:1494); pre-emptive TEVAR may â†“ late complic.

item.title: Treatment-acute mesenteric ischemia
item.description: Treatment-acute mesenteric ischemia IVF, NPO, optimize hemodynamics (minimize pressors), broad-spectrum abx, anticoagulation w/ heparin Â± tPA (for occlusive disease), IV papaverine (vasodilator; for non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia)

item.title: Treatment-acute pancreatitis
item.description: Treatment-acute pancreatitis Fluid resusc.: aggressive in 1st 24 hrs, even if mild. 20 mL/kg IVB â†’ 3 mL/kg/hr. Goal â†“ BUN & Hct over 12â€“24 h.

item.title: Treatment-acute respiratory distress syndrome
item.description: Treatment-acute respiratory distress syndrome [[methylprednisolone]]

item.title: Treatment-adrenal insufficiency
item.description: Treatment-adrenal insufficiency Acute insufficiency: volume resusc. w/ normal saline + hydrocortisone IV (see below) Chronic insufficiency: (1) prednisone ~4â€“5 mg PO qam or hydrocortisone 15â€“25 mg PO qd (2/3 a.

item.title: Treatment-anaphylaxis
item.description: Treatment-anaphylaxis Epi: 0.5 mg IM (0.5 mL of 1 mg/mL solution) q5â€“15min as needed. For those who do not respond, IV infusion starting at 0.

item.title: Treatment-Anemia of chronic inflammation
item.description: Treatment-Anemia of chronic inflammation treat underlying disease Â± iron and/or erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA; eg, Epo). Iron if ferritin <100 or Fe/TIBC <20%.

item.title: Treatment-aortic aneurysms
item.description: Treatment-aortic aneurysms (Circ 2010;121:e266 & 2016;133:680; JACC 2020;76:201; NEJM 2021;385:1690) Goal is to prevent rupture (50% mortality prior to hospital) by modifying risk factors Risk factor modification: smoking cessation; statins to achieve LDL-C <70 mg/dL BP control (goal SBP 100â€“120): Î²B (â†“ dP/dt) â†“ aneurysm growth; ACEI a/w â†“ rupture risk (Lancet 2006;368:659); ARB may â†“ rate of aortic root growth in Marfan (NEJM 2008;358:2787) Mod CV exercise OK, no burst activity requiring Valsalva maneuvers (eg, heavy lifting) Indications for intervention (individualized based on FHx, body size, sex, anatomy) TAA: sxs; ascending Ao â‰¥5.

item.title: Treatment-aortic-regurgitation
item.description: Treatment-aortic-regurgitation Acute decompensation (consider endocarditis as possible acute precipitant): surgery usually urgently needed for acute severe AR, which is poorly tolerated by LV IV afterload reduction (nitroprusside) and inotropic support (dobutamine) Â± chronotropic support (â†‘ HR â†’ â†“ diastole â†’ â†“ time for regurgitation) pure vasoconstrictors and IABP contraindicated In chronic AR, management decisions based on LV size and fxn (and before sx occur); low diastolic BP and high resting HR associated with mortality (JACC 2020;75:29) Surgery (AVR, replacement or repair if possible): Severe and sx (if equivocal, consider stress test) Asx and either EF â‰¤55%, LV dilation [LVESD >50 mm or LVESDi (indexed to BSA) â‰¥ 25 mm/m2 (JACC 2019;73:1741)], or undergoing cardiac surg Transcatheter AoV implantation (TAVI) being explored (JACC 2013;61:1577 & 2017;70:2752) Medical therapy: vasodilators (nifedipine, ACEI/ARB, hydralazine) if severe AR w/ sx or LV dysfxn & not operative candidate or to improve hemodynamics before AVR.

item.title: Treatment-ascites
item.description: Treatment-ascites â†“ Na intake (1â€“2 g/d); restrict intake of free water if Na <125 Diuretics: goal diurese ~1 L/d.

item.title: Treatment-bacterial endocarditis
item.description: Treatment-bacterial endocarditis Empiric NVE or PVE >12 mos post-op: vanc + CTX PVE <12 mos post op: vanc + CTX Â± gentamicin (if OK renal fxn)

item.title: Treatment-bronchiectasis
item.description: Treatment-bronchiectasis Acute exacerbations: antibiotics directed against prior pathogens; if no prior Cx data â†’ FQ Chronic mgmt: treat underlying condition, chest PT, inhaled hypertonic saline, bronchodil.

item.title: Treatment-Candida species
item.description: Treatment-Candida species Mucocutaneous Clotrimazole, nystatin, fluconazole, itraconazole Candiduria (if pyuria or sx of infxn) Fluconazole or intravesical ampho if severe infxn, immunosupp.

item.title: Treatment-cholangitis
item.description: Treatment-cholangitis Antibiotics (broad spectrum) to cover common bile pathogens (see above) ampicillin + gentamicin (or levofloxacin) Â± MNZ (if severe); carbapenems; pip/tazo ~80% respond to conservative Rx and abx â†’ biliary drainage on elective basis ~20% require urgent biliary decompression via ERCP (papillotomy, stone extraction, and/or stent insertion).

item.title: Treatment-cholecystitis
item.description: Treatment-cholecystitis (Ann Surg 2013;258:385; NEJM 2015;373:357) NPO, IV fluids, nasogastric tube if intractable vomiting, analgesia Antibiotics (E.

item.title: Treatment-cholelithiasis
item.description: Treatment-cholelithiasis (Am Fam Physician 2014;89:795; J Hepatol 2016;65:146) Cholecystectomy (CCY), usually laparoscopic, if symptomatic (earlier is better) CCY in asx Pts if: GB calcification (â†‘ risk of cancer), GB polyps >10 mm, stones >3 cm; Pts undergoing bariatric surgery, cardiac Tx candidates, hemolytic anemia (sickle cell)

item.title: Treatment-chronic pancreatitis
item.description: Treatment-chronic pancreatitis (JAMA 2019;322:2422; Lancet 2020;396:499) Pancreatic enzyme replacement (may â†“ pain by reducing CCK). Rx routine vitamin D & Ca.

item.title: Treatment-cystic fibrosis
item.description: Treatment-cystic fibrosis Lancet 2021;397:2195) Acute exacerbations: may be assoc w/ persistent drop in FEV1 (AJRCCM 2010;182:627); continue aggressive airway clearance, target abx based on sputum cx (incl double coverage for PsA); common pathogens include PsA, S.

item.title: Treatment-diabetic foot infections
item.description: Treatment-diabetic foot infections (CID 2012;54:e132) Mild infxn: oral abx. Target GPCs (diclox, cephalexin, or amox/clav); use TMP-SMX or doxy for MRSA.

item.title: Treatment-diverticulitis
item.description: Treatment-diverticulitis (JAMA 2017;318:291; NEJM 2018;379:1635; Gastro 2021;160:906) Mild: outPt Rx indicated if Pt has few comorbidities and can tolerate POs PO abx: (MNZ + FQ) or amox/clav for 7 d; liquid diet until clinical improvement No abx is noninferior to abx in uncomplicated diverti (Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol 2021;19:503)

item.title: Treatment-epidural abscess
item.description: Treatment-epidural abscess Antibiotics (typically MRSA and gram-negative coverage initially then narrowed based on culture data) Â± surgery (decompressive laminectomy and debridement) for failure to improve on medical Rx.

item.title: Treatment-fever of unknown origin
item.description: Treatment-fever of unknown origin Empiric abx not indicated (unless Pt neutropenic or critically ill) Empiric glucocorticoids not indicated unless strong suspicion for specific rheumatologic dx Stop unnecessary meds (only 20% with a med cause have eos or rash) Up to 30% of cases remain undiagnosed, most spontaneously defervesce (wks to mos)

item.title: Treatment-glomerulonephritis
item.description: Treatment-glomerulonephritis (AJKD 2020;75:124 & 2020;76:265) If acute GN/RPGN suspected, give 500â€“1000 mg methylpred. IV qd Ã— 3d ASAP while awaiting bx results.

item.title: Treatment-hemoptysis
item.description: Treatment-hemoptysis Death is from [[asphyxiation]]çª’æ¯ not exsanguination; maintain gas exchange, reverse coagulopathy and Rx underlying condition; cough suppressant may â†‘ risk of asphyxiation Inhaled tranexamic acid promising (Chest 2018;154:1379) nebulized TA (500 mg tid) Massive hemoptysis: put bleeding side dependent; selectively intubate nl lung if needed Angiography: Dx & Rx (vascular occlusion balloons or selective embol of bronchial art) Rigid bronch: allows more options (electrocautery, laser) than flexible bronch Surgical resection

item.title: Treatment-Hepatorenal syndrome HRS
item.description: Treatment-Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) if critically ill â†’ vasopressor (eg, norepinephrine or vasopressin) + albumin (1 g/kg, max 100 g, bolus daily) to â†‘ MAP 10 mmHg.

item.title: Treatment-hyperaldosteronism
item.description: Treatment-hyperaldosteronism (SCNA 2014;94:643) Adenoma â†’ adrenalectomy vs. medical Rx w/ spironolactone or eplerenone Hyperplasia â†’ spironolactone or eplerenone; GRA â†’ glucocorticoids Â± spironolactone Carcinoma â†’ adrenalectomy

item.title: Treatment-hypernatremia
item.description: Treatment-hypernatremia Restore access to H2O or supply daily requirement of H2O (â‰¥1 L/d) [[Replace free H2O deficit]]

item.title: Treatment-hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state
item.description: Treatment-hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state Rule-out possible precipitants; ~15% mortality due to precipitating factors Aggressive hydration: initially NS, then Â½ NS, average fluid loss up to 8â€“10 L Insulin (eg, 10 U IV followed by 0.

item.title: Treatment-hypertension
item.description: Treatment-hypertension Every â†“ 5 mmHg â†’ ~10% â†“ ischemic heart disease, stroke, and HF (Lancet 2021;397:1625) Lifestyle modifications (each may â†“ SBP ~5 mmHg) weight loss: goal BMI 18.

item.title: Treatment-hypertensive crises
item.description: Treatment-hypertensive crises (Circ 2018;138:e426) AoD, eclampsia/severe preeclampsia, pheo: target SBP <140 (<120 for AoD) in 1 hour Emerg w/o above: â†“ BP by ~25% in 1 h; to 160/100â€“110 over next 2â€“6 h, then nl over 1â€“2 d Acute ischemic stroke (w/in 72 hr from sx onset): <185/110 before lysis initiated, o/w target <220/120 (same SBP goal for ICH) Watch UOP, Cr, mental status: may indicate a lower BP is not tolerated [[IV Drugs for Hypertensive Crises]] HTN urgency: goal to return to normal BP over hrs to days.

item.title: Treatment-hyperthyroidism
item.description: Treatment-hyperthyroidism Î²-blockers: control tachycardia (propranolol also â†“ T4 â†’ T3 conversion) Gravesâ€™ disease: either antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine (NEJM 2016;375:1552) methimazole: 60% chance of recurrence after 1 y; side effects include pruritus, rash, arthralgia, fever, N/V and agranulocytosis in 0.

item.title: Treatment-hypocalcemia
item.description: Treatment-hypocalcemia also treat concomitant vitamin D deficiency; Endocrine 2020;69:485 ä¹Ÿè¦æ²»ç™‚ç¶­ç”Ÿç´ D ç¼ºä¹ç—‡ Severely symptomatic: Ca gluconate (1â€“2 g IV over 20 min) + oral Ca + calcitriol (but takes hrs to work) Â± Mg (50â€“100 mEq/d); 10% CaCl2 in codes or via CVL

item.title: Treatment-hypokalemia
item.description: Treatment-hypokalemia (JAMA 2000;160:2429) If true potassium deficit: potassium repletion (â†“ 1 mEq/L â‰ˆ 200 mEq total body loss) Dosage: 40 mEq PO q4h, 10 mEq/h (IV), 20 mEq/h (central line), 40 mEq in 1 L IVF

item.title: Treatment-hypopituitary syndromes
item.description: Treatment-hypopituitary syndromes Replace deficient target gland hormones Most important deficiencies to recognize and treat in inpatients are adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism; if both present, treat with glucocorticoids first, then replace thyroid hormone so as not to precipitate adrenal crisis

item.title: Treatment-mitral-regurgitation
item.description: Treatment-mitral-regurgitation Treatment (Lancet 2016;387:1312; Circ 2021;143:e72) Acute decompensation (consider endocarditis as possible acute precipitant): surgery usually urgently needed for acute severe AR, which is poorly tolerated by LV IV afterload reduction (nitroprusside) and inotropic support (dobutamine) Â± chronotropic support (â†‘ HR â†’ â†“ diastole â†’ â†“ time for regurgitation) pure vasoconstrictors and IABP contraindicated In chronic AR, management decisions based on LV size and fxn (and before sx occur); low diastolic BP and high resting HR associated with mortality (JACC 2020;75:29) Surgery (AVR, replacement or repair if possible): Severe and sx (if equivocal, consider stress test) Asx and either EF â‰¤55%, LV dilation [LVESD >50 mm or LVESDi (indexed to BSA) â‰¥ 25 mm/m2 (JACC 2019;73:1741)], or undergoing cardiac surg Transcatheter AoV implantation (TAVI) being explored (JACC 2013;61:1577 & 2017;70:2752) Medical therapy: vasodilators (nifedipine, ACEI/ARB, hydralazine) if severe AR w/ sx or LV dysfxn & not operative candidate or to improve hemodynamics before AVR.

item.title: Treatment-mitral-stenosis
item.description: Treatment-mitral-stenosis Medical: Na restriction, cautious diuresis, Î²B, AF control, sx-limited physical stress Antibiotic Ppx recommended if h/o RHD w/ valvular disease for 10 y or until age 40 Anticoag w/ warfarin (not DOAC) if: AF; prior embolism; LA clot Mechanical intervention indicated if sx severe MS; reasonable if asx severe MS but PASP >50 mmHg and morphology favorable for PMBC; consider PMBC if non-severe MS but exertional sx and hemodyn signif w/ exercise, or if asx severe MS and new-onset AF Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC): preferred Rx if RHD; â‰ˆ MVR if valvuloplasty score <8, Ã˜ if mod-severe MR or LA clot Surgical (MV repair if possible, o/w replacement) if PMBC contraindicated Calcific MS: surgical MVR if severe & highly sx; use of transcatheter aortic prosthesis experimental and w/ high rate of complications (Circ CVI 2020;13:e008425) Pregnancy: if NYHA class III/IV â†’ PMBC, o/w medical Rx w/ low-dose diuretic & Î²B

item.title: Treatment-nephrotic syndrome
item.description: Treatment-nephrotic syndrome (NEJM 2013;368:10) General: protein suppl.; diuretics for edema; treat hyperlipidemia, Na restriction (<2 g/d) ACEI or ARB: â†“ proteinuria â†’ slow nonimmunologic progression of renal disease

item.title: Treatment-Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease NAFLD
item.description: Treatment-Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) wt loss (â‰¥10%), exercise, DM control, liraglutide (Lancet 2016;387:679), statins (Metabolism 2017;71:17), vit E in Pts w/o DM (Hepatol 2018;67:328), bariatric surgery (World J Hepatol 2019;11:138).

item.title: Treatment-of-hyponatremia
item.description: Treatment-of-hyponatremia NEJM 2015;372:55; JASN 2017;28:1340; CJASN 2018;13:641 & 984) [[Approach to treatment-of-hyponatremia]]: Frequent lab draws and IVF rate adjustments are cornerstones of treatment [[Rapid correction of Treatment-of-hyponatremia]]: [[Effect of IV fluids-treatment-of-hyponatremia]] [[Effect of 1 L infusion in 70-kg male]] åˆ†é¡ï¼š [[Treatment of Hypovolemic hyponatremia]] [[Treatment of SIADH]] [[Treatment of Hypervolemic hyponatremia]]

item.title: Treatment-osteomyelitis
item.description: Treatment-osteomyelitis Antibiotics: based on cx data. If clinically stable, consider holding antibiotics until bone bx obtained. Duration depends on Rx strategy/goals of Rx management (eg, 6 wks for vertebral osteo; Lancet 2015;385:875).

item.title: Treatment-Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
item.description: Treatment-Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria supportive care (iron, folate, transfusions); consider anticoagulation. Allogeneic HSCT for hypoplasia or severe thrombosis. Pegcetacoplan (binds C3, prevents complement cascade activation) superior to eculizumab (Ab inactivates terminal complement C5s) in â†“ hemolysis & stabilizing Hb levels (NEJM 2021;384:1028).

item.title: Treatment-pericardial tamponade
item.description: Treatment-pericardial tamponade Volume (but be careful b/c overfilling can worsen tamponade) and âŠ• inotropes (avoid Î²B) Avoid vasoconstrictors b/c will â†“ stroke volume & potentially â†“ HR Avoid positive pressure ventilation b/c it can further impair cardiac filling (Circ 2006;113:1622) Pericardiocentesis (except if due to aortic/myocardial rupture, for which emergent surgery is treatment of choice; if too unstable, consider small pericardiocentesis to prevent PEA) Surgical drainage considered if fluid rapidly reaccumulates, loculated, or hemorrhagic

item.title: Treatment-pleural effusion
item.description: Treatment-pleural effusion Symptomatic effusion: therapeutic thoracentesis, treat underlying disease process Parapneumonic effusion (Chest 2000;118:1158) uncomplicated â†’ antibiotics for pneumonia

item.title: Treatment-pneumonia
item.description: Treatment-pneumonia CAP (outPt) Amoxicillin, azithro, or doxy (avoid latter two if >25% resistance locally) CAP (ward) [3rd-gen ceph + azithro] or levoflox; omadacycline â‰ˆ FQ (NEJM 2019;380:517)

item.title: Treatment-polyuria
item.description: Treatment-polyuria 1Â° polydipsia: treat psychiatric illness, check meds, restrict access to free H2O Osmotic diuresis: address underlying cause, replace free H 2O deficit (see â€œHypernatremiaâ€ for formula to calculate) and ongoing losses Treatment of Diabetes insipidus Central DI: desmopressin (dDAVP, 1st line), low Na/protein diet + HCTZ, chlorpropamide Nephrogenic DI: treat underlying cause if possible; Na restriction + HCTZ (mild volume depletion â†’ â†“ delivery of filtrate for free H2O absorption), consider amiloride for Li- induced DI (Kid Int 2009;76:44), indomethacin (NEJM 1991;324:850) or trial desmopression Pregnancy-induced DI: due to vasopressinase from placenta, âˆ´ Rx w/ dDAVP

item.title: Treatment-Portal vein thrombosis PVT
item.description: Treatment-Portal vein thrombosis (PVT) Treatment: Acute: If noncirrhotic, LMWH â†’ warfarin or DOAC Ã— 6 mo, or indefinitely if irreversible cause.

item.title: Treatment-Primary sclerosing cholangitis PSC
item.description: Treatment-Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) supportive care, fat-soluble vitamins; no meds have improved survival UDCA may â†“ AÏ• & improve Sx, but unclear if beneficial

item.title: Treatment-pulmonary hypertension
item.description: Treatment-pulmonary hypertension Principles: 1) prevent & reverse vasoactive substance imbalance and vascular remodeling 2) prevent RV failure: â†“ wall stress (â†“ PVR, PAP, RV diam); ensure adeq systemic DBP Supportive Oxygen: maintain SaO2 >90â€“92% (reduces vasoconstriction) Diuretics: â†“ RV wall stress and relieve RHF sx; gentle b/c RV is preload dependent Anticoag: not routinely used; â†“ VTE risk of RHF; ?

item.title: Treatment-Pure red cell aplasia
item.description: Treatment-Pure red cell aplasia : thymectomy if thymus enlarged; IVIg if parvovirus and immunosuppressed (Clin Infect Dis 2013;56:968); immunosuppression/chemoRx if CLL or idiopathic; supportive care w/ PRBC transfusions; ?

item.title: Treatment-sexually transmitted infections
item.description: Treatment-sexually transmitted infections (MMWR 2021;70:1; JAMA 2022;327:161) Syphilis 1Â°/2Â°/early latent: PCN G benzathine 2.4 mil U IM Ã— 1 3Â°/late latent: PCN G 2.

item.title: Treatment-skin and soft tissue infections
item.description: Treatment-skin and soft tissue infections (CID 2014;60:169) Urgent surgical exploration with debridement of necrotic tissue and ID consultation Empiric antibiotics: [pip/tazo or ceftriaxone + metronidazole or carbapenem] + [vanco or linezolid].

item.title: Treatment-syncope
item.description: Treatment-syncope (JACC 2017;70:620 & 2019;74:2410; EHJ 2018;39:1883) Arrhythmia, cardiac mechanical or neurologic syncope: treat underlying disorder, ? ICD if Brugada pattern, sarcoid, ARVC, early repol + syncope Vasovagal: avoidance of triggers; physical counterpressure; consider â†‘ Na & fluid intake, fludrocortisone or midodrine (JACC 2016;68:1; Ann Intern Med 2021;174:1349); SSRI; ?

item.title: Treatment-Vitamin B12 deficiency
item.description: Treatment-Vitamin B12 deficiency 1 mg B12 IM qd Ã— 7 d â†’ q wk Ã— 4â€“8 wk â†’ q month for life

item.title: Treatment-Wilson disease
item.description: Treatment-Wilson disease chelation w/ D-penicillamine (supplement B6 as D-pen inactivates); alternative is trientine (â†“ toxicity w/ â‰ˆ efficacy, but $$), ammonium or bis-choline tetrathiomolybdate (investigational) may â†“ neurologic deterioration compared to trientine.

item.title: Triage-pneumonia
item.description: Triage-pneumonia qSOFA predicts poor outcomes, prolonged ICU stay, and in-hospital mortality if >2 of 3: RR>22, AMS, SBP<100 (JAMA 2016; 315:801)

item.title: tricuspid-regurgitation
item.description: tricuspid-regurgitation TRICUSPID REGURGITATION (Circ 2014;129:2440; Lancet 2016;388:2431) Fxnl etiol (90%): RV dilation, PHT (may be 2Â° to L-sided dis.), large L â†’ R shunts 1Â° etiol: myxomatous, IE, pacemaker leads, RHD, CTD, XRT, Ebsteinâ€™s, carcinoid, tumors Holosystolic murmur, 3rd/4th ICS, â†‘ w/ insp (Carvalloâ€™s sign); S3; prominent cv wave in JVP Consider repair/replacement in severe TR (eg, ERO â‰¥0.

item.title: Tricyclic antidepressants-toxicology
item.description: Tricyclic antidepressants-toxicology Hypotension, seizures, arrhythmia, â†‘ QRS, â†‘ QT IVF resuscitation, IV sodium bicarbonate, vasopressors

item.title: Troponin
item.description: Troponin 99th %ile w/ rise and/or fall in approp. setting is dx of AMI (Circ 2018;138:e618) [[Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction (2018)]]

item.title: Tuberculin skin test
item.description: Tuberculin skin test (TST/ PPD): inject purified protein intradermally, examine for wheal 48â€“72 hrs later. Interpret based on max diameter of induration, not erythema.

item.description: Tubulointerstitial proteinuria (usually <1â€“2 g/d) â†“ reabsorption of freely filtered proteins â†’ lose globulins Etiologies ATN; AIN [[Fanconiâ€™s syndrome]]

item.title: type

item.title: type 1 MI
item.description: type 1 MI includes detection of a rise and/or fall of cTn with at least one value above the 99th percentile and with at least one of the following: Symptoms of acute myocardial ischemia; New ischemic electrocardiographic (ECG) changes; Development of pathological Q waves; Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality in a pattern consistent with an ischemic etiology; Identification of a coronary thrombus by angiography including intracoronary imaging or by autopsy.

item.title: type 2 MI
item.description: type 2 MI includes detection of a rise and/or fall of cTn with at least one value above the 99th percentile and evidence of an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand unrelated to coronary thrombosis, requiring at least one of the following: Symptoms of acute myocardial ischemia; New ischemic ECG changes; Development of pathological Q waves; Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium, or new regional wall motion abnormality in a pattern consistent with an ischemic etiology.

item.title: type 3 myocardial infarction
item.description: type 3 myocardial infarction Cardiac death in patients with symptoms suggestive myocardialischaemia and presumed new ischaemic EcG changes before cTn values become available or abnormal meets criteria for type 3 MI

item.title: Uremia
item.description: Uremia hemodialysis indication: pericarditis, encephalopathy, bleeding [[Residual syndrome]] Classical signs of uremia are: progressive weakness and easy fatigue, loss of appetite due to nausea and vomiting, muscle atrophy, tremors, abnormal mental function, frequent shallow respiration, and metabolic acidosis.

item.title: Uremic bleeding
item.description: Uremic bleeding Uremia â†’ platelet dysfunction including â†“ aggregation, impaired adhesiveness Treatment: dDAVP, cryoprecipitate, correct anemia (improves plt aggregation and adhesion by increasing plt interactions with endothelium), consider holding anti-plt agents

item.title: valve-replacement
item.description: valve-replacement (Circ 2021;143:e72) Based on symptoms: once they develop â†’ AVR needed Indicated in: sx severe (stage D1; D2; D3 if AS felt to be cause of sx); asx severe + EF <50% (stage C2); or severe (stage C1) and undergoing other cardiac surgery Reasonable if: asx severe (C1) but either sx or â†“ BP w/ exercise (can carefully exercise asx AS to uncover sx; do not exercise sx AS), very severe, â†‘ BNP, rapid progression Growing data to support AVR in asx severe AS (NEJM 2020;382:111; Circ 2021;143:e72) Type of valve: mechanical reasonable if Pt <50 yrs, bioprosthetic if >65 yrs or cannot tolerate long-term anticoagulation; individualize if 50â€“65 yrs Transcatheter AoV implantation (TAVI, see below) attractive alternative to surgery Medical (if not AVR candidate or to temporize): careful diuresis prn, control HTN, maintain SR; digoxin if â†“ EF & HF or if AF; avoid venodilators (nitrates) & âŠ– inotropes (Î²B/CCB) if severe AS; avoid vigorous physical exertion once AS modâ€“severe ?

item.title: What are the most commonly encountered fever patterns
item.description: What are the most commonly encountered fever patterns Sustained or continued (little variability from day to day): this used to be the pattern of lobar pneumonia , steady until abruptly resolving by either crisis or death.

item.title: Wilson disease
item.description: Wilson disease (World J Hepatol 2015;7:2859) Recessive disorder of copper transport (mutation in ATP7B) â†’ copper overload Epidemiology: 1 in ~30,000 w/ age of presentation generally ranging from 3 to 55 y

item.title: Wolff-Chaikoff effect
item.description: Wolff-Chaikoff effect Excess iodide transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification (step 2) In individuals with a normal thyroid, the gland escapes from this inhibitory effect In individuals with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease (Hashimoto’s thyroiditis or Graves’ disease), the suppressive effect may persist

item.description: Wonâ€™t Breathe as Etiologies of High elevated PaCO2 decreae RR Respiratory Drive Voluntary hypervent. NI Pimax & A-a grad Metabolic alkalosis 1Â° neurologic: brain- stem stroke, tumor, 1Â° alveolar hypovent 2Â° neurologic: sedatives, CNS infxn, [[hypothyroidism]]

item.description: Workup for effusion r/o infxn: usually apparent from Hx & CXR; ? value of âœ“ acute and convalescent serologies

item.description: Workup for idiopathic VTE (NEJM 2015;373:697) Thrombophilia workup âœ“ if âŠ• FH; may be helpful but consider timing as thrombus, heparin and warfarin Î” results Useful for relatives, if dx APLAS (given requires warfarin), or if not planning lifelong anticoagulation for Pt.

item.title: Workup for non-AG metabolic acidosis
item.description: Workup for non-AG metabolic acidosis Evaluate history for causes (see above) âœ“ urine anion gap (UAG) = (UNa + UK) â€“ UCl UAG = unmeasured anions â€“ unmeasured cations; NH4+ is primary unmeasured cation (represented by UCl).

item.title: Workup of acute hypoxemia
item.description: Workup of acute hypoxemia Cyanosis: when >5 g/dL of deoxygenated Hb in vessels of skin/mucous membranes. Central: â†“ SaO2 (pulm disease, shunt); abnl Hb [metHb, sulfHb, COHb (not true cyanosis)]

item.title: Workup of chronic diarrhea
item.description: Workup of chronic diarrhea positive: FOB WBC calprotectin lactoferrin Inflammatory: stool culture, colonoscopy positive: fecal fat Malabsorption: * Based on hx: âœ” tissue transglut.

item.title: Workup-acid-base disturbances
item.description: Workup-acid-base disturbances Traditional or physiologic approach (BrÃ¸nsted-Lowry definition of acids & bases) Determine primary disorder: âœ“ pH, PaCO2, HCO3 Determine if degree of compensation is appropriate [[Compensation-for-Acid-Base-Disorders]] Alternative approaches Base excess/deficit (NEJM 2018;378:1419) Strong ion difference or â€œStewart Methodâ€ (NEJM 2014;371:1821)

item.title: Workup-acute kidney injury AKI
item.description: Workup-acute kidney injury (AKI) H&P: meds, contrast, or other nephrotoxins; â†“ PO intake, HoTN, infxn/sepsis; trauma, myalgias; BPH/retention. Search for insult 24â€“48 hr prior â†‘ Cr.

item.title: Workup-acute liver failure
item.description: Workup-acute liver failure (Clin Liver Dis 2017;21:769) CBC, PT/PTT, LFTs, lytes, BUN/Cr, NH3, pH, arterial lactate, acetaminophen level, HIV, amylase/lipase, viral serologies (qv) in all Pts, with additional labs as below if suspected

item.title: Workup-cirrhosis
item.description: Workup-cirrhosis (Am J Gastro 2017;112:18; Lancet 2021;398:1359) Abd U/S w/ Doppler: liver size & echotexture, r/o HCC, ascites, âœ“ patency of vasculature

item.title: Workup-fever in a returned traveler
item.description: Workup-fever in a returned traveler Routine testing: CBC w/ diff, BMP, LFTs, BCx, UA, rapid malaria test Fever in a traveler from a malaria zone is malaria until proven otherwise; consider a medical emergency â†’ hospitalization & empiric Rx.

item.title: Workup-fever of unknown origin
item.description: Workup-fever of unknown origin Initial: CBC w/ diff, CMP, ESR, CRP, 3 sets BCx (off abx), U/A, UCx, CXR Additional workup based on sx: ANA, RF, cryoglobulin, LDH, CK/aldolase, SPEP, TFTs, PPD or IGRA, HIV Ag/Ab Â± PCR, RPR, EBV serologies, CMV PCR, HBV/HCV serologies Consider imaging: chest & abd CT, tagged WBC scan, FDG-PET, TTE, LE duplex US Tissue dx: consider bx of LN (excisional preferred), liver (especially if â†‘ AÏ•), TA (for GCA), BM, kidney (RPGN)

item.title: Workup-for-AG-metabolic-acidosis
item.description: Workup-for-AG-metabolic-acidosis (AJKD 2021;78:A16) âœ“ for ketonuria (dipstick acetoacetate) or plasma Î²-hydroxybutyrate (Î²OHB) nb, urine acetoacetate often not present in early ketoacidosis due to shunting to Î²OHB; âˆ´ acetoacetate may later turn âŠ• but does not signify worsening disease If âŠ– ketones, âœ“ renal function, lactate, toxin screen, and osmolal gap If obtunded or â†‘â†‘ AG, check osmolal gap (OG) = measured osmoles â€“ calculated osmoles Calculated osmoles = (2 Ã— Na) + (glucose/18) + (BUN/2.

item.title: Workup-glomerulonephritis
item.description: Workup-glomerulonephritis (JAMA 2017;318:1276) Acute GN/RPGN Â± lung hemorrhage is an emergency â†’ requires early Dx and Rx UA + sediment (dysmorphic RBCs) âœ“ ANCA, anti-GBM, C3/C4, SPEP, serum FLC

item.title: Workup-hyperkalemia
item.description: Workup-hyperkalemia (Crit Care Med 2008;36:3246) Rule out pseudohyperkalemia (IVF w/ K, tourniquet, hemolysis, â†‘ plt or WBC), rule out transcellular shift

item.title: Workup-hypernatremia
item.description: Workup-hypernatremia âœ“ Uosm, UNa, volume status (vital signs, orthostatics, JVP, skin turgor, BUN, Cr)

item.title: Workup-hypokalemia
item.description: Workup-hypokalemia (JAMA 2021;12:1216) Identify transcellular shifts & treat. TTKG validity questioned (Curr Op Nephro 2011;20:547). âœ“ UK:Cr: >13 mEq/g â†’ renal loss; <13 mEq/g â†’ extrarenal loss (AJKD 2019;74:682)

item.title: workup-hyponatremia
item.description: workup-hyponatremia (JASN 2012;23:1140 & 2017;28:1340; Crit Care 2013;17:206; NEJM 2015;372:55) Workup History: acute vs. chronic (>48 h); sx severity; risk for neuro complications (alcoholism, malnourished, cirrhosis, older women on thiazides, hypoxia, hypoK) [[Measure plasma osmolality]] For hypotonic hyponatremia, âœ“ [[volume status]] [[Measure Uosm]] If euvolemic and â†‘ Uosm, evaluate for glucocorticoid insufficiency and hypothyroidism If available, consider FEUricAcid as >12% suggests SIADH (J Clinc Endo 2008;93:2991) Backlinkï¼š [[sodium and water homeostasis]]

item.title: Workup-nephrolithiasis
item.description: Workup-nephrolithiasis Non-contrast CT 97% Se, 96% Sp (ureteral dilation w/o stone suggests recent passage); U/S (Se 57%, Sp 98%) may serve as initial test in stable patient (NEJM 2014;371:1100)

item.title: Workup-nephrotic syndrome
item.description: Workup-nephrotic syndrome (BMJ 2008;336:1185) U/A + sediment: usually benign; Â± oval fat bodies (â€œMaltese crossesâ€; NEJM 2007;357:806) Measure proteinuria: 24-h urine or spot urine protein/Cr ratio (not accurate in AKI), renal bx

item.title: Workup-of-hematuria
item.description: Workup-of-hematuria (NEJM 2021;385:153) Urine dipstick: âŠ• if â‰¥3 RBCs; âŠ• dipstick and âŠ– sediment â†’ myo- or hemoglobinuria

item.title: Workup-syncope
item.description: Workup-syncope (etiology cannot be determined in ~40% of cases) (JAMA 2019;321:2448) H&P incl. orthostatic VS have highest yield and most cost effective R/o life-threatening dx including: cardiac syncope, severe blood loss, PE, SAH History (from Pt and witnesses if available) activity and posture before the incident precipitating factors: exertion (AS, HCMP, PHT), positional âˆ† (orthostatic HoTN), stressors such as sight of blood, pain, emotional distress, fatigue, prolonged standing, warm environment, N/V, cough/deglutition/micturition/defecation (neurocardiogenic), head turning or shaving (carotid sinus hypersens.

item.title: Zygomycetes
item.description: Zygomycetes Epidemiology: diabetes (espec. those w/ prior DKA), heme malignancy, neutropenia, transplant, chronic steroids, iron overload, trauma, h/o voriconazole Rx or Ppx Clinical: rhinocerebral = severe periorbital/facial pain, swelling, vision changes, sinusitis, opthalmoplegia, nasal ulcerations/ necrosis, HA.

item.description: Î±1-antitrypsin deficiency early-onset panacinar emphysema or signif basilar disease, 1â€“3% of COPD cases. Suspect if age <45, lower lungs affected,

item.title: Î±1-antitrypsin deficiency Î±1-AT
item.description: Î±1-antitrypsin deficiency (Î±1-AT) (J Hepatol 2016;65:413; NEJM 2020;382:1443) Abnl Î±1-AT â†’ polymerization in liver (cirrhosis) & uninhibited protease activity in lung (emphysema).
